i'm late to the party but is it safe in a general sense no how do you make it 'safe' * enable parental controls * ensure the account has the below chat filter on * do not let them enter the roleplay community at that age the rp community there isn't exactly safe for people under i'd argue that the roleplaying community is the most dangerous place for a person under to be on the site as its full of legitimate predators and extremely unhinged teenagers * if they ever mention 'condo' games check their account if they've played any games with a name that mentions 'condo' pull them aside and tell them to never play that kind of game again those games are essentially sex roleplay games * if possible just turn off the chat feature it'd be for the best until they're older and know how to safely talk online * if you let them play in games that are multiplayer supervise them * don't enable voice chat keep in mind by 'safe' i do not mean safe there are still risks they may see something in a poorly age rated game or on the avatar of another player like a shirt with an obscene image on it edit added extra dot point

i know this thread is a few months old but as an \[f\] that has played roblox since i was a child i really need to give you some advance warning that the website page won't tell you unfortunately for me i had to find out the hard way of how awful some individuals can be online at a very young age roblox isn't all bad but you have to be very careful with how you set your childs account up for starters if your children are under **please** and i repeat **please** go into **settings** then **privacy** and then set all the **communication settings** to ***no one*** this basically means your child can not talk to strangers in game or through the website this might seem a little extreme but it will prevent anyone trying to get into contact with your kids unfortunately older people do try and ask for social medias such as a popular app called [discord] where your child can talk freely with a stranger without roblox's protection as someone that got roped into this scheme early on please do take my word on this discord is not a place for children the age rating is stated + but this place could easily be + from what goes on on there another thing parents to be aware of is that you must put a **pin** on your childs account or all your settings are **easily changeable** you can do this by going into **settings** then **parental controls** and then by enabling **parent pin** you can also choose here which experiences you want your child to be able to access such as + + and all ages roblox should **automatically switch your childs account to a safe account** if their age is below anyways but making sure these additional steps are in place will ensure their safety i'm writing this because i don't think any child should have to endure the trauma i went through with this platform please keep your kids safe

deleting roblox account  i'm a divorced father with a son who i've always bonded well with we've shared countless moments playing video games splashing about in the pool and engaging in all sorts of entertaining activities however things took a turn when roblox became a part of our lives   initially he asked me for worth of robux the game's in game currency considering my profession in the video game industry i didn't see any harm and agreed to his request as his requests became more frequent i decided to get him a premium subscription   as i received the receipt notifications in my email i started noticing that the amounts were significantly increasing on one occasion he claimed he had been hacked and in his distress persuaded me to give him he was upset but not in an entitled way i empathized with his anguish because of my own experiences with gaming   the situation escalated yesterday when i discovered he had spent around in total on robux our relationship became strained as i denied his request for another he reacted very aggressively saying hurtful things he even called his mother and accused me of physical abuse   we've always engaged in playful physical activities like picking him up and throwing him into the pool classic father son roughhousing but now he claimed these actions were abusive and that he had been masking his discomfort all along his accusations were deeply distressing because i genuinely thought we were sharing joyous moments when he would exclaim again dad again   this altercation with his mother i believe was his attempt to manipulate both of us and it all stemmed from the robux issue i have access to his roblox account and i've been contemplating whether i should delete it the game seems to be adversely affecting him as he even attempts to barter chores such as eating his vegetables for robux i'm left wondering should i take the drastic step of secretly deleting his account

doesn’t seem like it will stop until both of you put your foot down and say no more kids will try anything to get what they want and i believe it’s our job to show them what’s correct and what’s incorrect and stand our ground on it i would remove his access to the game simply for trying to manipulate each of you just change his password and don’t let him have it back until he stops these shenanigans

you sound well intended but everything you did here was backwards the more he became invested in it the more you rewarded him he starts asking for more and more money so your solution is a premium subscription now you're at the point that's most backward of all the game seems to be adversely affecting him as he even attempts to barter chores such as eating his vegetables for robux this should have been a requirement for every cent he got from you instead it's like you handed him the power and now he's using it when you mention secretly deleting it's obvious this thing needs to go but you also want to have a convo with him for example ask him directly curious not mad why he would claim abuse for the pool antics when it's obvious he loved it and you both know it's not true i mention this because his online life needs to be evaluated beyond roblex certain minor changes at his age are expected but he still needs strict controls in place hopefully you and his mom can reach agreement on what this is

her she doesn't have a cell phone she does have a tablet but she can only download apps that we approve of and one issue that we've had in the past is communication with strangers whenever we allowed her to download the fitbit app we didn't realize there was a social media section and on that section a bunch of strange men were trying to contact her simply from her posting a selfie and they were trying to get her to exchange photos with them luckily she didn't and we were able to catch it but now we are in new territory roblox is a game that she's always loved to play but we know she's been able to communicate privately on there as well so we were able to block all the chats and go in the privacy settings and block any private chats that's great but apparently there are certain worlds or servers that you can join that have their own separate chat feature that you can't block so adopt me is one of the games or servers that doesn't allow you to block the chat feature and now she can technically chat with people through that does anyone have any advice for me we have all the parental controls taken care of but she did add a couple of friends not people she knew but just random strangers but it wasn't a big deal to me because they couldn't chat but now she can chat with him through adopt me i really want her to enjoy roadblocks and i want her to be able to play it but i'm hoping someone has a way for me to make this a little bit safer for her while still allowing her to play stuff that are around er age on there and thank you for not being super judgmental and thank you for helping me out here also keep in mind that there's a weird keyboard bug with reddit when i type things out on my phone through voice typing apparently erasing some things will cause everything to double up or triple up so if you see any mess ups it's because i'm voice texting everything

a couple of years ago our school had a presentation for parents about online safety presented by a female detective who often goes undercover to catch predators she looks a lot younger than she is and often took part in raids and stings as well as maintaining online profiles on various platforms she basically told us in no uncertain terms that any online platform or game where chat is a function is a breeding ground for predators and it is never a matter of “if ” but definitely a matter of “when” someone unsavory contacts a child it’s not limited to roblox there were dozens of apps and games she listed that she regularly catches predators from…it was jarring and my husband and i just decided to not promote or allow those games for our kids they can play a lot of games meaning we don’t punish them we tell them why we don’t like certain games and we provide plenty of alternatives but roblox was a big one that the detective mentioned so we have sort of banned it from the get go i would also screenshot what you can and send it to your state police crimes against children sex crimes dept they need screenshots but they can definitely step in i’m so sorry you have gone through this it’s horrifying

here's a blog post from someone who looked at roblox more in depth with regards to safety for young children i actually had to block roblox for my son quite a while back because we had set up a child account and he found out from a friend how to create his own account i believe the company behind it has tried to take various steps to create a safe environment but like most internet games it's not going to be enough to be truly safe for unsupervised play for young kids since you mention a phone a helpful tool you might want to look into is circle by disney roughly it's a device you plug into your home network and it allows you to control internet access for all devices on your network and have a lot of easy to use fine grained control over specific game services and such it might help your situation it's been helpful to me because supervised play is just not a reality for parents so these tools help to keep some controls for young kids to be within configured bounds it's not really useful for older kids because they'll find ways around it but it's helpful for younger kids i also echo the other commenter about common sense media fantastic resource for checking things out beyond just generic ratings so you can make your own call as a parent i use it all the time for when my son asks about a new game movie show

there’s a few different responses here depending on the scope of the relationship with grandma you can disable the phone line and turn the phone into basically an ipod i’m team ination but android does have significantly better parental controls regardless of the model of the phone your kid has you can effectively turn it into a toy for her and remove the ability for her to call grandma or access the internet etc take out the sim card factory reset parental controls etc this option renders mil powerless and keeps your kid happy you can return the phone to mil this will upset kiddo but also send a clear message to mil about the boundary stomping “my daughter is not allowed to spend time with people who give her gifts behind our back and encourage secrecy from us [this establishes the scope of what you can control you don’t control mil you control your daughter’s social circle] please do not give gifts to kid without checking with us first please do not encourage her to keep secrets from us [this is clearly defining the boundary for mil] if we are unable trust you to respect us with this we will be unable to trust you around our daughter we will take a [insert time block here] break from spending time with you [the last two sentences may or may not be necessary depending on how combative or explanatory you need to be with mil] then when it happens “we already discussed with you that my daughter is not allowed to spend time with people who give her gifts behind our back and encourage secrecy from us we’ll try again in [# of months] i’ll call on [date] ” block her number and enjoy the silence for great information on setting and maintaining boundaries check our nedra tawwab glover’s “set boundaries find peace” you can keep the phone and power it off and leave it in the dark recesses of your closet or dresser you can use it for outgoing calls only like the other commenter suggested—block her number and unblock only when you are ready to let daughter talk to her when mil asks you can deflect “it’s always getting lost in the kids messy room battery is always dying ” or be more direct “kid isn’t old enough to have it all the time we’ll let her have it unsupervised when she is ” this is the most neutral response albeit with an upset kid

a lot of people are jumping to rather harsh judgements based on a very small amount of information and context you have given us your feelings are your feelings i’m not going to tell you they are invalid however without knowing more about your overall relationship with your mil it’s difficult to make a judgement about what kind of response makes sense if you were to say that your mil has a history of frequently crossing boundaries and overall disrespect then that is one thing if you were to say that she does that occasionally that would be another if this is her first time then that is another so you have to look at the situation in the totality you and your wife together have the right to decide what devices your child has access to i’m not going to comment on the reasonability of that because again there are too many variables to consider that i don’t know however your preferences don’t necessarily make you mil a boundary stomping ogre like some people have suggested i’m probably closer to your mil’s age than yours i know a lot of people in this age range who just aren’t aware of all the things you mentioned in the same way you are also we come from a generation where you could call on a land line and if someone was home they would usually answer so it’s been an adjustment to the new ways cell phones create a different paradigm i usually try to pull back my focus a bit and see what the message is that the person is trying to convey even if they do so clumsily here it seems like your mil would like to have more contact with your daughter again i don’t know the totality of your circumstances so it’s up to you to take all of that into consideration but i’d be trying to see if that’s something that makes sense and if there’s a way to go about it that is more in line with your preferences for your child’s safety etc is it feasible to work out some other way to address the desire for more contact i don’t know the answer to that but it might be worth considering

i think my concern with the good bad secrets concept is that the person asking them to hide something in this case grandma but in more alarming instances a child predator is not going to sell the idea as a bad or harmful secret that will hurt someone but as a ‘good’ secret that will help them eg “we need to keep this phone secret from mummy and daddy so that grandma can call you if she needs to talk to you and we can talk to each other whenever we want to isn’t that great but don’t tell mummy and daddy it’s our secret if mummy and daddy find out they would stop us being able to talk on the phone and that would be so sad ” most kids would struggle to understand that grandma’s secret phone or uncle gary’s secret touching time are a bad harmful thing because they are being told by a trusted adult that it is a good thing and keeping this a secret is helping their trusted adult and doing the right thing it relies too much on a child’s ability to perceive and weight up the help hurt implications of concepts they don’t even understand you’re right that keeping a secret for a friend is helping them avoid embarrassment but there is a different between secret keeping and info dumping we don’t need to each recount loudly at dinner about the poos we did on the toilet today but that doesn’t mean it’s a secret we can tell a trusted adult if we need to but don’t need to shout it from the rooftops to strangers the important aspect is that our kids feel like they can tell us anything including being worried about a suicidal friend even if somebody has insisted they keep it secret the difference is that some things are *private* and we can choose who we trust to share them with some things are a *surprise* and we can’t tell until a special moment but things that are *secret* and we aren’t allowed to tell others ever are unhealthy

my yo screwed up big time he spent over in robux in the past couple of weeks not only was it charged to a card i rarely check on but some of it also went to a random hsa card that only could’ve been obtained by physically going into my husband’s wallet he’s been asking for a phone obviously the answer is no for a very long time but now what my yo has an ipad and plays roblox i don’t want to punish her for her brother’s crime but i don’t know how we can continue with screens in our home after this i’m at a loss and we need to address this asap **edit his ipad is several years old my yo recently got her ipad and it has the payment authorization feature this is a good point that i need to install this feature on my son’s account i welcome all tips and tricks with regards to technology i also welcome suggestions for punishments for my son’s behavior i’m not opposed to quitting screens altogether as some have suggested… not sure how realistic that is though update he is going to work to pay off the debt roblox said apple is the one who needs to refund so we are working with them still pending the hsa charges did not go through but i've included his attempts an extra in his total debt based on our state minimum wage he will have it paid off in about hours or six months if he puts in hour of work per day we made him add up every single charge by hand there were over of them he doesn't get screens until he has paid us back when he does get his ipad back it will have the new ios feature that requires parent authorization for anything and everything we are tabling the conversation about a phone until he is at least we are also going to have him volunteer at a local charity of his choice many people commented that this is my fault and perhaps to some extent it is but at the end of the day he knew what he was doing he knew it was wrong and yet he did it anyway the fact that he went into my husband's wallet really is my main concern
roblox is actually well known for refunds in these situations they just delete the account after so the purchases get voided talk to roblox

report this to robux they will most likely refund the money and close ban the account explain to your child how serious stealing money is they truly may not know the value of money do not have a credit card attached to an account like this if you want to give them some money to use buy them a gift card for the service you need to setup parental controls microsoft family works apple has some there are also third party apps like qustodio none are perfect sadly

do some math with him take minimum wage in your state and have him calculate the hours it would take to earn what he spent then have him spend one afternoon doing nothing but chores and clock those hours that evening calculate until what date he would have to work every afternoon to make that much money if you gave him minimum wage if you feel that is sinking in then you can extend the grace to say because you're a kid and i want you to learn from mistakes not be miserable forever you're going to do just hour of extra chores daily until x date not every free moment after that date we will make a screen time use contract which will be quite strict as we work on building the skills you need to navigate the internet safely as others have said lock your kid's ability to make purchases on the device i'm not as familiar with ipad but with my kids' fire tablet i have to approve all purchases from my device so i don't have to worry also from the time my kids started playing apps we've had frequent and open conversations about the purpose of games being to make money and framed in app purchases as ways to trick you into spending money we've met some games that can't be beaten without purchases and talked about how it feels unfair and disappointing but it's all part of the game developers' plan to make money which isn't a bad thing they deserve to support their families but being aware is important don't just get rid of screens alltogether now that you know he has a problem putting off screens til he's older will just mean he has the same weaknesses but with higher stakes and no parental safety net you need to actively teach practice and monitor good online habits now so they can be his default when he's on his own

i agree with some other commenters here he probably has no idea the gravity of what looks like or what it could really do for the family however he is old enough to know stealing the credit card was wrong i would sit down with him and divide by the minimum wage in your state to find out how many hours of work he needs to do to come off punishment hell even take takes into account with it so he understands how long it really takes to save have him do extra chores and log his hours until the is worked off until it is no games no tv no screens etc then i would make him write a letter of apology to you for putting you in a situation where you need to come up with a bill you weren’t expecting he sure should understand why what he did was wrong after that and he may have more gratitude or understanding for just how expensive life is and the things you provide for him

first your son is at an age where he needs to experience the consequences preferably natural consequences that are directly related to his poor choices of his actions you need to make provisions for him to pay back what he stole obviously you need to consider his ability to do what you’re requiring of him and if he needs transportation or something else that he can’t provide for himself you will need to be willing and committed to help him with those things i understand that you’re dealing with some big emotions yourself and it might feel to you like you need to be punitive; but you will find that the best way for him to learn a lesson is for you to remain in control of your emotions state the facts clearly including what it cost and maybe give him a set time to come up with a plan for making it right whether you want to do that or just think for yourself about how you want him to make it right the important thing is that you want him to realize the weight of what he did and what he will need to do to make it right; but you don’t want to overwhelm him or break his spirit he needs to know that you believe in his ability to make better choices he needs to hear your praise along the way when he comes through now is a good time to talk to him about the importance of trust at his age he really needs to understand that trust is something that is very important to protect; and when he breaks trust with you it won’t be easy to fix broken trust takes more than a recognition that what he did was wrong more than genuine remorse it requires acceptance of the consequences that are caused by his breach of trust it requires that he demonstrate his trustworthiness and maturity in his consistent persistent willingness to demonstrate his ability to handle responsibilities and consequences without complaint when you ask him for something it’s his opportunity to show you that you can trust him and that he’s maturing as well as growing that needs to happen in small ways at first and when he follows through make sure to tell him that was what you wanted to see let him know you’re pleased with him

as someone who has studied cognitive psychology and has spent years doing user experience design for a living my professional assessment is that most free to play games like roblox are highly manipulative at best and straight up unethical at worst **there is no age at which these types of games are appropriate even most adults don't have the training to recognize all the different ways that they're being manipulated let alone have practiced strategies for overcoming social conditioning needed to resist ** robert cialdini has written a lot in cognitive psychology about what he's deemed principles of persuasion which are general techniques that are used to influence people's behavior here's a brief summary of the principles [ his book influence is a good read if you want to dig in a little deeper [ applying some of them to a common pattern you'll see in these types of games * if you login every day you get a free reward * sets the stage for exploiting reciprocity because they did something nice for you your instinct is going to be to do something for them by complying with what they're asking * the reward gets better each consecutive day you play * exploits consistency if you've convinced someone to do something once they're far more likely to keep doing it * the rewards reset if you miss a day * exploits scarcity when something is taken away even if it's free people instinctively perceive the cost of the loss as greater than what the item would have cost to acquire * after you get the bonus you'll presented with a limited offer to purchase something only available to the first x players y players have already redeemed * exploits scarcity seeing that it's limited makes it appear more valuable and drives instinct to acquire something before it runs out * exploits social proof seeing that a large number of others have taken the offer makes you more likely to consider it a good idea to do as well * exploits reciprocity you're far more likely to take an offer because they've given you rewards single player games that cost real money are almost always a better choice

what’s the minimum wage in your area for me it’s around £ hr shifts days a week = hours a week so £ a week i’d start by taking away all screens for at least a month the time it would take to pay that back on minimum wage + extra chores in that month & restrict internet access until you think he she has learned their lesson you can go into the router settings and prevent specific devices from accessing the internet even while the router is on & the rest of the family can continue to use it without any issue my cents & what id personally do with my kids if they did that

try to get a refund you need to treat the stealing and the spending differently the spending needs more of a life lesson than a punishment the stealing needs punishment though you need to make sure he understands how utterly disappointed you are that he did that and how wrong it is to steal if possible reach out to a friend or family member that has the opportunity to make him do a day's worth of work i own a business and have tons of shitty chores that would be fine for a yo that needs to learn about hard work and the value of money have him spend a saturday with someone you know who has a business a farm a large yard that needs work an elderly relative that could use someone to carry their groceries and do chores a garage that needs to be cleaned out etc and preferably let him start early then use the commenters tip who advices to calculate for him how many of those days he'd have to work to make back take him grocery shopping explain that money that is spend on one thing can't be spend on something else he spend so now you need to save not buying the phone he was gonna get is a good start the remaining amount needs to come out of the grocery budget that might mean no snacks this week no soda no brand cereal whatever would drive the point home for him explain to him what he saved and why that's necessary this might mean your yo also doesn't get her favorite groceries but this isn't a punishment it's a lesson and that lesson is useful for both of them sit him down and explain how stealing is one of the worst things you can do he betrayed your trust and that makes you upset and disappointed he needs to think of a way to make it up to his dad but he's also grounded for *whatever amount of time you'd think is appropriate* he's also not allowed any screentime when he's grounded and will only get that privilege back if he was well behaved during the time he was grounded and made an effort to apologize to his dad

this is the difference between a debit card and a credit card the legal protections on both are somewhat similar but the reality is different you can dispute charges on your debit card but the money is already gone from your account and the money will remain gone from your account unless the bank resolves the challenge in your favor with a credit card a disputed transaction is permanently on hold and you don't owe the money to the bank until the transaction is resolved this is a decent reason why you should have a credit card for online purchases even if you prefer to run a primarily cash household

anyone can create their own games which is both good and bad this is the reason why there are so many games on the platform there’s a lot of new games being added frequently game creators can add in game purchases purchased with robux which can be special features like unlimited in game currency special boosts like being able to jump higher unlock special packs etc it’s not necessary to buy these sometimes it makes the game faster and easier there are many different types of games in roblox my family enjoys the “tycoon” games where you earn “money” or whatever you’re collecting in the game and build your “base” or whatever you’re building in the game there’s zoo tycoons building and customizing your own zoo pizza restaurant tycoon store tycoon mall tycoon etc since there are a lot of games that are not appropriate for little kids it’s best to monitor them and even play with them we’ve been playing it for a few years and lo only plays on roblox when we’re playing with them they’re also only allowed to play games that we have played ourselves and added to their favorite list so we know it’s appropriate to name a few of our favorite games like work at a pizza place which allows you to earn money by “working” in various positions in a pizza restaurant and you can buy furniture for your home in game make your house bigger buy clothes and accessories in that game club roblox is a roleplaying game where it’s a city you have your own house that you can customize upgrade change work in different buildings roleplay in other careers like hospital police station daycare etc build a boat for treasure is where you build a boat using blocks and if you can pass the course at the end there is a treasure chest where you can earn coins and new building materials there’s a firefighter game not sure what it was called is great for little kids because you get to drive around the city in the firetruck and put out fires bee swarm simulator is a game where you collect pollen from flowers take it to your hive where your bees make honey and you use the honey as “money” to unlock more bees bee hive spots and to upgrade your tools there’s also shooting games for older kids and adults … we don’t play those but there is a game called big paintball that we play sometimes which is just teams blue vs red trying to get the other team my husband found a game like rust that he enjoys playing as well there’s a whole bunch of different kinds of games that’s good for little kids and it’s fun for parents to play with their kids too if you play it with little kids you can set their profile to their age and it won’t show inappropriate words in the chat for kids under i think which is based on the age on their profile you can also turn off the chat to prevent kids from seeing any chat at all from other players and it also prevents them from being able to chat there’s even an account restriction which only allows curated content from what i’ve seen from using this though there are some games like work at a pizza place that aren’t allowed i think you can still see all the games but it will only allow you to play specific games

roblox hi parents for those of you who may not be familiar with roblox it's a website application that is kindof like an mmorpg for kids there's hundreds of different games from survivor tv show clones to fashion shows to zombie games its free to play but there is paid content as well the site is specifically targeted to kids and teens there's a chat feature that can be disabled and it is somewhat heavily auto moderated i want to take a moment and share my experiences with it along with a question or two and to invite you to do the same my year old and year old have been playing games on the platform for a while and both seem to love it recently the year old has gotten interested in the social aspect friends and chat as i said the chat feature can be disabled and i explained to her that if we run into problems with chat that we'd turn it off we've worked hard to set expectations so that everyone is clear on the front end the friend aspect is rather like the steam game platform and you can request that people become your friend it doesn't seem to have much impact other than that you can see if they are in a game and join a game that they are in as well as messaging the computer monitor faces our family living room so its easy to see at a glance what's going on i don't tend to hover constantly but when she's reading or typing in the chat window i make a point to give it a fairly frequent look it is as much an exercise in guarding against nefariousness as it is in trying to help and guide her in understanding online interactions we have of course talked about safety and predators online but tbh i'm more worried about hard or soft bullying online which we also talk about one of the things that i'm really working with her on is this friends thing there's one person that she's befriended that has a cute sounding name along the lines of unicornsparkle the year old is delighted when this other person is in the same game with her and talks to me about this person i get the feeling that she's drawn to this person largely by their name and avatar outfit and less by any quantitative qualities i don't mind that but i'm working to help her get an understanding of what it means to be friends with someone in an online setting she has expressed an interest in learning to touch type so we've found a couple of resources for that i think this may help her now and later as her typing is pretty slow and basic and i've noticed a couple of times that her chat responses come so delayed as to lose all context and once or twice have been misunderstood or misconstrued here's some of the rules and expectations that we have setup for her * do not give out your name we let her come up with a 'nickname' so that she can offer her name if asked without giving out her personal information * don't give out other personal info location etc someone asked her age the other day and she was quick to not give her actual age but after thinking about it a moment age doesn't seem like 'bad' information * no secrets * she won't be in trouble for anything that anyone posts or that she sees if she has questions about anything that she saw or read she can ask and we'll talk about them no judging * we expect her to be kind just as she would to someone in rl no namecalling making fun bullying etc * if someone says things that are unkind to her or other people she should avoid them and can let us know standing up against bullying is also encouraged * she uses the computer with our permission and asks if she's not sure of something we have the philosophy that there are dangers on the internet but we don't want to fall into the trap of believing that a child abductor is hiding behind every bush she's up to speed on safety in that regard and it is relatively easy to protect her from this threat she is far more likely to run into an unkind person or bully and it is more difficult to protect her from that i feel that by teaching her about these things early that i can help arm her with the information that she needs to be safe and healthy and have respect for herself and others in an online setting other parents what have been your experiences with roblox positive negative or otherwise if your children are into roblox at what age did they become interested in the social aspect of it and what did do you allow thanks edit format and spelling

pulling her out of school goes way too far home schooling is hard work and you need to do it for the right reasons if you do it just to shelter her from outside influences you will do her a huge disservice you won't be able to keep her safe from the world at least not forever and you need to come to terms with that one day she'll leave your home and enter the real world if you never expose her for these dangers and teach her how to keep herself safe kids don't grow an extra part of their brain which contains all the knowledge on how to handle the world and take care of themselves the night of their th birthday these are skills that need to be taught and practiced for years and years and years and sheltering her is the exact opposite of what you need to do to teach her these skills sit down with her and go over the chat with her explain what concerns you about it for example that he only told her his age after your daughter already told him she's explain that there are predators out there who mask themselves as kids in order to try and gain kids' affection so that they can sexually exploit them tell her that some people use being suicidal as emotional blackmail so that you do what they want because you're scared of hurting them so much that they end up hurting themselves tell her that even if someone is genuinely suicidal she shouldn't do things she's not comfortable with and that if a suicidal person does end up hurting themselves it's never her fault explain that some predators specifically use roblox to target kids because they know that a lot of the players are year olds etc have the entire internet safety talk with her not telling anyone her name or where she lives not posting pictures of herself or that could identify the area she lives in not giving random internet strangers her number or address etc ultimately you can't keep her safe by controlling her maybe you can do it temporarily but in the long run it'll end up doing a lot more harm than good teach her how to keep herself safe you need to focus on raising a future adult

we just had to have the conversation again with my yo she came to the bank of dad asking for bucks of gas money to make it to payday bank of dad required her to produce an analysis of her spending over the last month and to explain why she didn’t have gas money i already knew since i have access to her bank account but she needed to go through the motions of understanding where the money went and then we sat down with her and asked her to figure out how much gas she needed every week to make it to work what that would cost with a fudge factor for additional driving around town and variability in the price of gas and to determine how much money she had left to spend on whatever and letting her know that when the car insurance renews she’s on the hook for hers going forward and then once she did all that getting a loan is a lot of paperwork after all we then negotiated the terms of the payday loan and how much the vig was gonna be she was gonna have to mow the lawn and do some extra chores on top of paying back the principal which is a pretty usurious vig when you think about it but it’s much better for these lessons to be learned budgeting not blowing all your money on twitch what a terrible idea payday loans are how much money adulting costs why doordash is a stupid idea when you’re just sitting at home craving a box of mcfries etc when the stakes are a tank of gas rather than when they’re “not being able to make rent or the power bill” or “guido is threatening to come break your legs because you didn’t pay the loan”

eh alright i’ll bite the legal minimum age to sign up for accounts on most social media platforms even ones that are going to be “monitored” by parents or are “family” accounts is thirteen whilst there may not be any major crack downs happening to address the large amount of underaged and unmonitored users that doesn’t mean letting your kid have one is harmless or necessary plain old texting on whatever built in messaging app that comes with every phone is still something people do every day without requiring any fancy stickers or reactions from another app to keep it fun at the same time however there’s gonna be a day where your kid is going to need a phone and her impulse control issues will no longer be an excuse to not give her one though that doesn’t necessarily mean she can just put whatever she wants on it without you knowing being unable to see what she’s doing iphones can be set as a child account that you can have a access and control over from your phone that she will not be able to easily bypass without you knowing many other types of phones have apps or similar system programming that allow the same level of monitoring with very few workarounds even the most tech savvy kid would have trouble figuring out without leaving a trail behind for you to follow ultimately it’s your choice as to when if your daughter gets a phone of her own and what she can do on it but educating her on cyber safety and what’s expected of her before giving her a phone will be more beneficial in the long run rather than just holding out until it’s absolutely necessary or she’s old enough to pay for her own and having her be glued to it

as long as she can chat with friends use apps supervised i don't see a problem with it however have you thought of getting a phone for her and providing screentime with a parental content controls online so you can see and moderate what she watches i know having an hour or two of screentime a day was always cool with my parents as kids and around i really started to get into fanfiction and anime so it was fun to read write and share on my ipod

the research about the negative effects of social media is so abundant it seems negligent at this point to give unlimited access to technology after knowing this the # advice my high school students give me is to keep my daughter away from devices and hold off on giving her a phone for as long as possible even teenagers are self aware enough to realize how bad it is for them

i think there needs to be a balance yes you don’t want her addicted to her screen but you don’t want to make it so she’s unable to connect with her friends on a relatable level so much of childhood is common experience and currently you’re denying her the ability to relate to her peers the danger with this attitude is that you’re making it this taboo thing the likelihood of her going online in secret and then not telling you if she encounters something wrong or dangerous online bullying predators porn becomes higher because she hasn’t been taught internet safety and she’s breaking the rules don’t set her up to fail or set her up to keep secrets life should be about balance i have a surprising number of friends who struggle with a good relationship with food because their parents banned certain kinds instead of teaching moderation and self control imo — she needs to learn the importance of moderation and maybe earning her screen time when she’s done her work rather than denying it to her completely

all american teenagers feel excluded there's literally nothing you can do to stop her from feeling misunderstood isolated and excluded sometimes but also roblox is a disgusting company that has done basically nothing to mitigate the rampant sexual exploitation of minors on their platform and their business model is openly built on the exploitation of minors' labor

to start i think you’re doing great i don’t know that anyone has a tried and true answer to any of this all we have are opinions that said as someone who lives in silicon valley i can assure you most parents who work in the tech industry limit their children’s exposures to social media in particular and in some cases do not even allow devices in their rooms family room computer type stuff i know this because i do not hesitate to ask every time i meet someone who works for these companies and i’m never shocked by their answer just angry because they are getting rich off something they know has an incredible downside to others children’s while protecting their own the best they can schools are beginning responsible tablet use in kindergarten now so that these kids can learn how to use them for educational purposes so between that and their limited use at home they’re getting plenty of exposure i know about five years ago there were signs in the middle schools here that said “wait until th” meaning wait until at least th grade to get them a phone or allow social media use i think maturity and responsible use has a lot to do with it and that comes with age perhaps someone else can update us on if that’s still the case regardless a lot of kids are being targeted on these platforms now by dealers trying to sell them prescriptions pills that are actually laced with fentanyl it literally just happened to audrina partridge’s year old niece this week and it’s led of an increase in shocking overdoses everywhere from young teens who are just curious and trying things that we might have found in our parents medicine cabinets once upon a time this is becoming a scary reality that a lot of people don’t talk about so regardless of what you decide please discuss this with your daughter so she knows how dangerous it is in the event any of her friends who do have social media are targeted

give them some supervised time on popular platforms teen culture is almost exclusively online these days preventing your child from accessing social media all together will isolate them from a majority of their peers let them “be in the know” so they can keep up with trends and events their friends are interested in you don’t want to make internet access or a phone feel scarce like a treat this can make your child over prioritize their time on social media encourage a healthy balance of digital and real life teach them to use social media to enhance real life maybe help your child create some of their own content
no right answer both yes and no can be correct in this case but if your child has adhd giving her free access to a phone is like giving an alcoholic a gift brandy you need to keep that in check

i was playing roblox at y old and im now i love that game with my whole heart yeah theres creeps but learning internet safety is sooooo valuable i had to learn it the hard way but now a days there are resources on how to manage roblox was there for me when i had no friends in real life cause i was kinda just to weird and had undiagnosed audhd and whatever other excuse or explanation roblox has a good system set up too for security just make sure to look at the settings and stuff maybe a gift card on holidays but roblox is easily a good introduction to internet culture without the scary bad influences especially the popular games on roblox

my son is and has a tablet buuuttt i have family link on my phone connected to his tablet he cannot download any games without my permission i can go on my phone to see what games he is playing i have complete control as to how many hours he can play and what apps i can ban he does have roblox but i turned off the chat on his tablet he can see others messages but he can't respond also with family link you can get it with a phone and you can turn it off or set time limits on any apps or on the tablet itself

i’m in the camp of delay especially social media internet communication apps as long as possible year olds don’t need smart phones i know what i did at on extremely limited dial up aol 🥴 that’s enough for me not to willingly participate in this pressured device ridiculousness for tweens i say from a place of not having to deal with it yet and also lots of fear a closely monitored with strict parental controls tablet with limited screen time keeps kids safe in parallel we should teach kids about why and how to navigate the internet safely within those boundaries and what red flags to be on the lookout for no matter how much you govern and lock down devices she’ll have a friend with a parent who won’t bother and you want her to be knowledgeable and confidently stand up for herself and learn from being impulsively sucked into something problematic online i agree with [wait til th] and even then i wouldn’t be opening the youtube flood gates

my mom did this exact thing so i went behind her back online and got into bad situations i'd let her have supervised time on social media to prevent this also no youtube sounds strange otherwise understandable

my child is he only has a phone for safety purposes only we have it pretty locked down with parental controls he has no social media and we don't allow that at all he basically uses it to play minecraft when he doesn't have his tablet or to listen to music off

well she’s going to use these apps on her friend’s phones eventually behind your back so your strict rules won’t matter you can’t “preserve her youth” just because you don’t like what the other youth are doing there are genuine safety concerns over using all of those apps but it’s better to teach kids how to use them responsibly my son has adhd and he’s always had access to youtube and roblox just not tiktok yet cause he’s but for the other apps we talk about what’s appropriate and what isn’t and he’s not allowed to chat or comment on anything i also watch the videos he watches with him and play roblox with him too and we set time limits so when he’s played for a long period of time he has to put his device down and go play read or use his imagination for a bit he used to throw a fit about that but he’s much better now and doesn’t fight it so yes you’re doing her a disservice you should educate her on self control what is and isn’t okay to do on these apps and how long is a healthy amount of time to spend on them and have conversations about what she does on these apps to keep open communication if you don’t know how these apps work learn or ask her to teach you cause if you don’t take the lead here her friends will

just as kind of a peripheral note that i think is worth considering apparently the vast majority of tech executives do not allow their teens on social media and or don't allow them to have phones you can google this there's been lots of reporting around it i just think that's really telling in terms of what they know that we don't about how ads and media are designed to keep us ever consuming anyway i think it's smart to keep things heavily locked down limited and monitored but i also think it makes sense to allow certain things in moderation only you can decide what's right for your family and your child my main suggestion is that if you start to loosen the reigns take baby steps and closely monitor your kid and any emotional behavioral changes and don't let your guard down as far as being attentive to how their media consumption social or otherwise is impacting their well being

id start to let her have supervised access with one at this point ie kids youtube she will start being able to make her own decisions too with your guidance even educational games be an option definitely a no no for social media

so i had a lot of restrictions when i was a kid about what media i could and couldn’t consume i grew up just as mobile phones became more popular for older teens i got my first ever nokia when i went to uni in classmates had razr or flip phones and many others didn’t have a phone what i learned from growing up with restricted access to pop culture was that yes it did affect how well i fit into some settings to this day at age people make all sorts of references to things that i don’t get but at it doesn’t really matter i feel you’re doing better for your kid than not the impact of screen time and the fragmentation of attention and inability to be bored are genuinely quite harmful when she’s older i would get her a dumb phone for safety she can get a smart phone when she has a job or saves allowance if this is something you do or when it’s needed for a job your approach of having it on tablet and not phone is a good one as an adhd adult this is one way that i manage and limit my own over use of screens

roblox is dangerous imho my kids are only allowed to play with people we actually know and they have been warned not to talk to anybody they don't know not to use their real names never to give out their ages what town we live in etc my kids got phones relatively early and i regret it they're too dependent on them now and i hate it

in my opinion you’re doing exactly the right thing especially if she’s got adhd those platforms do more harm than good anyway and in most cases have a minimum age older than your daughter to use i don’t think tiktok does though and it’s the worst one there are kid safe options like gabb phone or bark phone gabb phone looks like a smartphone but has no internet access bark phone does everything a normal smartphone does but it is all parent controlled and parent monitored you can see everything they do on it from your account and they can’t delete texts without permission one of those is what we will be getting my kids when they get to maybe or before that they won’t have anything there’s no need for it if i had my way they wouldn’t get a phone until they are driving but my wife will probably push for a little earlier i’m ok with that as long as it’s one of those phones

ultimately she will using the technology that you are preventing her from using **her entire life** and you should consider teaching her how to use it the worse thing that you can do to someone with adhd is shelter them i just want to put this into a different perspective for you what happens when she goes to college and you're not there to stop certain behavior or impose limitations adhd is not a disease dont treat it as such instead teach her life skills that help her navigate a society that was not made for her and it starts with responsible use of technology **poor impuse control doesnt mean she cant get better** but she needs the opportunity to practice so she can develop her skills

it depends on the child but screen time in our house has been permitted with parental supervision and restriction to age appropriate content as long as there's continued compliance to the house rules surrounding screen time barring any behavioral issues my personal rule for my son has been that as soon as he's autonomous enough to do things on his own i e walk to school by himself go to extracurriculars without my supervision hanging out with friends in the neighborhood without adults watching everybody's every move then a phone is necessary simply as a direct line of communication in case of emergency children with a parent nearby all the time do not need a phone because a parent is available to handle an emergency children without a parent or other trusted adults nearby will need something to act as a resource in case of emergency the age at which this autonomy can be achieved is so individual to every family child that it's just not useful to look at literal age suggestions for any of this i don't like the social media world we live in but that can be monitored the more i thought about removing what is really at its most basic a gps + device just because my kid might find some shitty app to use with his friends the more authoritarian i felt about it i believe it's my job to raise my son around more fulfilling people activities so that shitty apps games don't look so enticing to him when they will fly at him
children do not belong on social media you are doing the right thing there is no reason she needs a regular cellphone great job

my almost year old is not on social media she can play roblox but only on family desktop that is in the kitchen she does play video games we have had to crack down and make sure it’s only friends irl that she’s playing with no cell phone she has an apple watch with a phone number for calling she can text on there and her ipad but i control who whe contacts are some contacts that i am on the fence about like a boy she has a crush on she can use my phone to text so i can monitor most of her friends have cell phones and social media at i think you need to at least allow some access on your own device so she can start to navigate you don’t want her hiding things and accessing on the dl and you don’t want her going crazy once she gains access every kid is different so depends on the kid i have a year old too and she’s had social media since and a phone since she has always been responsible and not impulsive she’s done fine my almost year old is impulsive and makes poor choices so she’s waiting longer till we see some responsibility and better impulse control

prepaid flip phone we got one for our kid and it's working just fine for us portable cd player and hand held games and a strict lock down on her ipad there are also nicer minimalist smart phones that only allow text call and email but they're a little pricey and only work with a couple of phone services but it's probably what i'm gonna get for our term when she turns or kids don't need smart phones or social media

no your being an amazing parent my parents did not let me have a phone tablet anything until half way in to my senior year my rule for my kids will be when you have a good enough job to pay for the phone and the monthly bill for a year upfront then you can have one

yea you could be doint a disservice if you’re not prepared to give her more access to these spaces as she gets older you’ve basically cut her off form being able to communicate with her peers about what could be common interests and you aren’t giving her the opportunity to make the kind of choices that you feel you’ve raised her to make she may already feel alienated from other kids already and she’s going to have to make extra effort to find her place among them socially since she’s not going to be able to connect with them on a basis of shared interests parental controls are a available if you feel that she’s too impressionable to navigate youtube for appropriate content and other social spaces i think monitoring her use of these things instead of completely restricting them until proven necessary would be best compromise in this situation let her have a phone as well access to roblox and youtube and see if her behavior stays the same or if it’s going to cause her adhd symptoms to flare up and go from there edit don’t let her have tiktok though that dopamine pile will have her face plastered to her screen i know from personal experience because tiktok is who told me i had adhd in the first place after only one week on it the algorithm knows it’s users

i think to an extent she probably does feel quite isolated regardless of our feelings about phones and the internet they have become an integral part of daily life for the younger generations there likely is a gap between her and her peers because of how online the culture of this youngest generation is and i’m willing to bet there’s probably a lot of things she’s not exactly “in” on with the rest of them because of that but your intentions are good and i still think that limiting access is healthier in general especially after you mentioning that she has adhd and impulse issues all that stuff really does exacerbate the issue to a hefty extent particularly social media i’ve found it’s done a lot to decrease the attention spans of people by a ridiculous amount maybe there’s a compromise here where she can have limited access to a device and the internet in moderate quantities that way she’s not as left out i also think that if you make internet and phone use a very rare thing for her what will eventually happen is when she finally does get a phone because in this day and age she’ll probably eventually get one in her teens she’ll go crazy overboard with it in response i see the same thing in kids whose parents completely banned all tv or in kids whose parents forbid all soda and candy the minute their kids got access to those things they went crazy with overconsumption because they were never normalized to consume these particular things in moderation in a healthy manner you don’t want a phone the internet to become that sort of thing for her

keep her off socials and away from internet access as long as possible i don’t have time to link articles now but there is a great deal of scientifically studied relevant information to support that adolescents can be harmed greatly by having that kind of access there is no upside other than convenience keep her entertained in other ways letting her learn online navigation under your direct supervision is wise and prudent at her age keep it up

i think you’re doing great by allowing some access to technology but not completely keeping her from it when they get older you just have to adjust it’s hard but i do think you should try to integrate some stuff to make it seem like they aren’t missing out regular youtube can be pretty bad that’s why i like youtube kids you can pick individual creators and other content so that you know what they’re watching you can start by picking stuff and previewing it although i’m not sure at what age this becomes pointless tiktok is a hard no many predators on there and messed up stuff a kid that age doesn’t need to be exposed to there’s actually no value to it unlike youtube where there’s lots of easy to monitor content that can be educational or fun youtube is already not great for adhd kids if they tend to flip through stuff so tiktok would be a pretty tough one on the attention span with the short videos and whatnot roblox is tough there’s a lot of content on there that’s fine but the kids and adults may not be it helps that they’ve really limited what can be said on chat but if you’re still worried you can filter this by turning off chat options but i’m not sure how easy it would be for a kid her age to undo that and haven’t had to do that myself yet i recommend monitoring her chats with friends i personally know parents who’s children have sent images to friends that they shouldn’t have and those things have been shared and lots of bullying that can happen don’t do this behind her back i would say that you just need to have a conversation with her about how things can be safe and you want to make sure she is safe not that you are constantly looking at stuff but that you will check in occasionally to make sure everything is pg or if you feel like you don’t want to intrude at all there may be a way to prevent picture sharing etc on the kids messenger app i think in a couple years these restrictions can be lifted as you see fit but regardless you need to have a conversation with her about the internet if you haven’t already this can be as simple as hey just like the real world the internet isn’t safe always there is adult stuff that you don’t want to see and that there are people that may try to talk to you for the wrong reasons this is why you only talk to people that you know in real life that are your friends in chat if you’re on roblox and you’re playing with someone you don’t know do not give out personal information because we don’t know who they are and there’s no way of knowing you don’t want a stranger to know where we live or your full name because we don’t know if they are safe even if you think they may be nice in a couple years you can add more details as questions may arise another thing is you let your kid know that if there’s anything that they see or find on the internet that makes them feel weird or scares them they can always come to you and talk about it you won’t be mad there’s a lot of things children just won’t understand and may not be ready to be exposed to you’re there for them and can help explain anything that may be weird you’re right sometimes it can be a disservice when they get old enough to make those decisions or go behind your back and haven’t had any of this conversation or exposure to the internet it can put them in very dangerous situations you’re doing great hope this helps

there is gabb wireless which is a phone without internet you can take photos text amd talk my yo has one because we want to be able tor each her when she isn't with us but don't feel she needs internet on thr phone she has a computer and tablet and an old phone of mine to use at home only for data so she doesn't need a smart phone just food for thought

it could very ostracize her i have a daughter the same age but she like many kids have had phones for years now my daughters use iphones they have to get permission that is sent my iphone and requires my face id to download any apps i also have their log ins for all of their accounts you could still get her a phone but keep the apps under control by making all app downloads need permission and keep her to youtube kids rather than all access to youtube i would still make it a requirement that you need to be in the room when she uses youtube kids or if you allow tiktok you must be in the same room i understand the reasoning you want to keep her from these platforms kids her age and younger are given unmonitored access to these things which i believe is dangerous and far too much freedom a good balance can be found and as my kids grow and they are able to earn more freedoms

i have a yr old soon to be i gave him a phone he turn it off in school he doesn’t have social media or tiktok he also has adhd he is not included in the class chat and i think is better he use roblox to play with his friends they have parental controls they can’t upload anything without my consent also i have him the phone to be able to call me or dad now he can be at practice alone and call me when is time we don’t have land phone so is very convenient he communicates with all my family called grandma’s etc the thing is the most you don’t allowed something is worst better to teach them how to use things i will not allow him to use social media yet but definitely he feels more secure to be able to call anyone if he needs to

our boys got phones at the year before secondary school as it would be then they'd be expected to walk to and from school alone the important thing for kids this age is not removing access it's limiting access put strong parental controls on the phone i use family link which sets a time limit doesn't allow download of apps without parental acceptance and sends alerts should they try and access anything they shouldn't at nearly i still have these controls on my twins phones with their consent as they recognise they have poor impulse control otherwise and would spend hours on their phones we also have xboxes and playstations with similar controls it's up to you how you do it but we did the above with the understanding that phones were a privilege not a right and that their father and i reserve the right to check through messages etc if we're worried we haven't done that for a long time

when i f was young i was never allowed to do what the other kids did in the name of protecting me it made me an outcast and i never did fit in even in high school i allow my kids to be a part of the culture that surrounds them with parental controls in place

the thing is the more u restrict the more sneaky they get i wasn't allowed a phone i was when i got one and only because i was walking to and from school i wasn't allowed any social media or to give out my number i didn't listen to that i got social media all under fake names so my parents wouldn't find me i had to put my phone on the charger in the loungroom every day at pm i'd uninstall all social media apps before it went on charge cause i knew my mum would look and after they went to bed i'd get up and sneak my phone when i'd get busted i'd loose my phone for a period of time so i'd just wait till my mum left the house and go through her stuff to find it

my kiddo is younger but lots of her friends are already on tiktok roblox we've disallowed that along with other things like drinking soda sorry we're the parents and not ok with it we're keeping her safe

it's a difficult one and ultimately it comes down to what works for you and what you think is right for your child anything in moderation is mine and my partner's motto we allow my son a phone but there are certain lines around when and where he can use it and if he tries to abuse these there are penalties for this it's hard i would rather he didn't even have a phone at but it's the times all his friends communicate through it and we use it to keep in touch with him when he's out and about so we don't want to cut him off entirely it isn't perfect there are degrees of drama involved but we've found that trusting him he has returned this trust and the issues we occasionally have are around usage but not truthfulness which was the biggest concern we have we trust him to use it correctly and be honest if there are issues and building this trust we have found to be really important as he gets older and doesn't just view us as ogre parents who just shout no and he has to hide things from take everyone's advice but ultimately you need to make the call that you are comfortable with

i think roblox is wildly inappropriate for children i work with intellectually disabled adults that use the platform inappropriately and it has opened my eyes to the egregious nature of the game… that being said i cannot convince my stepdaughters bio parents that it’s not acceptable it’s not my decision anyway and it feels like a losing battle the internet is not a safe place for kids or tweens and this roblox thing is basically a playground for dangers of the internet and i never thought i would be the “uncool” adult to restrict my kids from things but … any parent letting their minor child in a role playing open source online community is really whacked out it’s no different than reddit
new parent here but i look up to this type of screen time regulation i think you will be doing a good service to them long term

no i don’t think you’re doing her a disservice my oldest will be in january and also has adhd she does not have a phone or ipad and i don’t see that changing anytime soon but she does have a kindle fire with parental controls enabled she hasn’t been deprived like your daughter she can call text facetime friends from my phone and she is able to play minecraft on the playstation or the computer she just isn’t allowed to use a multiplayer server her school issues everyone a chromebook so she is able to use that too but we monitor and regulate access after school and on the weekends just to ensure she’s getting her assignments done and isn’t getting distracted by other things she doesn’t have access to roblox or tiktok and her youtube access on my phone and the kindle fire is limited unfortunately it is not so limited on the chromebook and she has a tendency to doomscroll and watch content that has been questionable at times youtube has honestly been a huge issue for my kids and their access wasn’t always so limited but i’ve found that it works best for our family which is full of neurodivergent individuals to set those limits because right now they just aren’t great at creating and enforcing those boundaries for themselves— which is understandable and probably age appropriate and will hopefully improve as they grow and learn more of those skills we talk about this stuff openly and i tell her why i set these boundaries i also listen to my daughter when she feels like i’m not not being fair sometimes i agree with her and we change things up sometimes i don’t and i tell her we can’t compromise on “x” right now but let’s think of other ways i can help her feel like she has more agency control freedoms we also talk a lot about how what works for other families may not be what works for ours and that’s okay and ultimately it’s my job to keep her safe and ensure she’s accessing and using technology in age appropriate ways the school she’s at this year has hosted events before where experts come talk about how to stay safe online highlight the risks and dangers of social media etc so i plan on having her come with me when they host them this year because i think it’s important for her to be part of the bigger conversation too

in my opinion this is a bit strict i wouldn't allow tiktok regular youtube or roblox online but i would allow a phone with safeguarding restrictions i think it's important to teach kids how to safely use technology rather than banning it and ostracizing her from her peers has long term consequences on social development you can get her a phone and make it so she can't download apps and put software like bark on it to keep her safe also talk to her about the dangers if the internet make sure she feels safe coming to you with questions rather than asking google
with all the weird and dangerous trends happening in the internet mostly by her age of kids i dont think you're wrong waren'tnt allowing social media platforms either

my philosophy is allowance is to help my kids learn to spend money in ways that align with their values i want them to practice spending money on things so they get the experience of feeling like it was totally worth it and it totally wasn't i want them to learn to save up for things they want that's big and to donate to charity they believe in we force a split of save spend and give after that it's their money

nope i also hate it but it's their money if they want to use their planning and self control to learn how to get closer to something they want it would be kinda mean of me to try to control what they spend it on like what would be their motivation or what would they learn at that point if they're not even going to be able to get what they are working towards plus an added bonus if they don't have the money for the thing they want to buy then there's no reason to bother me with any begging they don't ask me for anything they want anymore i pay allpwance over cashapp my older two have cashapp cards and can check their balances on their phones and i use the savings account on my cashapp to keep up with my youngest son's balance

my perspective on allowance is that the purpose is to teach kids how to manage their money kids will be adults someday and adults make big choices with money that could have bid consequences letting kids make choices with their allowance even bad choices is giving them a chance to learn while the risks are low they can choose how to spend their money especially at this age with out the risk of ending up without food transportation utilities or housing instead i restrict what i buy for them partially to set the example and partially because i don't wanna buy that crap there are certain things that i will always buy like a book a special occasion outfit a souvenir on a special trip but even those things have limits and have to be reasonable there are also certain things i will never buy like robux i like to ask them the questions i think they should be asking themselves in this case i might say you can do that it's your money but also know that you won't get any more until insert allowance pay date so if something else comes up you won't have any money to buy it with is this the thing you really want with your savings i might even suggest they take a day to think about it the point here is that your kid is likely impulse spending they see a thing when they are playing the game they want it they don't yet have the skills to consider the outcome of that impulse spending with my kid it's helpful to be specific i point out places we plan to go or activities where she might also enjoy spending money sure you can buy that but i want to remind you we're going to the coast this weekend and we'll be near that candy shop you like if you don't have any money you won't be able to buy anything there do you want to think about this before you decide to buy the robux

when i was a kid my mom used to say my money burned a hole in my pocket realistically i had undiagnosed adhd and zero impulse control 🤣 as a kid who used to do the twenty years ago version of this same thing i think you should talk to him about setting up a budget that way he can save for what he wants while still having some extra robucks money maybe set him up with the envelope system it worked well for me when i was a kid since it was a visible thing get him a three ring binder with large envelopes with holes punched in them each with a label then help him figure out how much he wants to save for his bigger buy and how much he wants for extra robucks money and then maybe a third option for miscellaneous spending money for stuff like candy or little things when you’re out

of course if it's something super unhealthy dangerous or scammy i'll stop them if it's just a foolish to me purchase i'll try to dissuade them maybe give them a week to confirm their decision but if they are sure i'll let them but in the first place if they receive like at xmas or birthday depending on age i will set a limit on how much they can spend in the short term i tell the younger ones to look at the older sibling who was allowed to buy a laptop at age using savings accumulated over years plus parents and relatives all chipping in for xmas for cultural reasons my kids all have thousands of their money from gifts so i most definitely cannot let them spend it all willy nilly i am very strict on mobile in game purchases and things like robux it's a blanket no for cosmetic items and premium currency only paying for new apps games mods or new content something that adds to the play value or to remove ads from an otherwise great game is allowed i've had many conversations explaining to them how this industry works and how they exploit kids and people who are lazy addicted or have ego issues

i would look for other ways to help him learn how to make monetary decisions talk him through some of your own thought processes when you purchase things and think about the terminology you use eg if you say “we can’t afford the more expensive brand of breakfast cereal” you’re inadvertently implying that if you could afford it you’d buy it which basically encourages them to always spend their money on the things you want whereas if you say “we choose not to buy the expensive brand of breakfast cereal because it is not good value we choose to save that money for other things that are more worthwhile” then you’re showing your kids how to weigh up options to spend money on things they really value
