op have you made a decision on this as a kid i had a dollar weekly allowance that my parents gave me and i had the same lack of impulse control having my own money didn't mean shit to how i spent it even as an adult i have struggled to control it if i didn't stick to my budget i think the point of having that kind of control as a child is to simulate the idea of being an adult maybe plan out a trip or an event that they have to save up to with a hard deadline and if he misses it then so be it pointing out the lesson of budgeting that can be ingrained into him at a young age will be the best one thing to point out that i point out to all parents dealing with gamer children is that microtransactions are designed to take advantage of the user even those discount' items are calculated in a way to be the most enticing and best believe any data being acquired from purchase history and purchase habits will be used to manipulate the user freedom for your kids to spend their money however they want is great and all but being cognizant of the fact that they haven't developed the physiological mechanism to defend against that kind of manipulation is just as important we don't know what the effect of having everything at our fingertips has will do to the development of the human race but i wish you luck

tldr; we don’t allow the balance to be and no more money is allowed to be withdrawn until the next pay period usually bi weekly we also absolutely limit the amount of robux allowed it’s basically gambling practice and as such is treated like a hobby and we wouldn’t spend all our money on a hobby personally i treat it like a bank in practice for real life so essentially i have a maximum withdrawal and the balance can never be you can really argue for that last dollar but i make it clear that no money is coming to them unless it’s honorably earned my daughter started hiding money around the house to beat my system so she has some money in the bank and some in hidden spots for emergencies lol for me i base big purchases on what’s in the bank and i usually try to keep at least of what’s there so for there would have to be at least left and no more money allowed to be taken out until the next pay period we go by our literal pay periods they also have the opportunity to apply for jobs around the house if there are any garden work extra chores etc mainly trying to get kid into understanding the limits of their money i would not care where the money goes but we also went through the return vs non return like if she gets something on amazon it’s returnable and she can get her money back but clothes on roblox are lost dollars forever
at age we set boundaries no slime or stuffies we have enough it’s everywhere but birthday money or something blow it on whatever you like

i have a yr old boy and a yr old girl the former is an absolute pain when it comes to chores but after repeating myself times and threatening to take away ban him from using something he’ll eventually do chores like clean the playroom or pickup his junk out of the living room my daughter is much better at listening but needs to be reminded quite a bit in terms of allowance we just started doing it starting late re my daughter i know and excuse the slight bit of self promotion but i’ve actually spent the past several months building a startup product around the idea of allowance chores kids autonomy and online shopping in the app i set a base allowance of week and then tie a series of chores weekly and one off bonuses to “micro payments” for example i currently have a weekly chore to unload the dishwasher all week which is worth ; and then i have a one off “bonus” chore for successfully completing soccer juggles so far she’s really into it and is always asking for extra stuff to do the unique thing about my product is it’s connected to an online shopping experience for kids it’s curated and categorized and kids can only spend what they have so she’s already bought herself a pop puck this fidgety toy thing and is now saving for something bigger she’s set her eyes on in the shop she loves having the autonomy to spend her savings when she wants and how she wants and as a parent i know the shopping experience is kid friendly and completely safe if anyone is interested in giving it a try themselves please send me a dm i’m currently seeking out some early beta testers

i think it's different because micro transactions can be toxic they are designed to be addicting and really prey on those with poor impulse control and the fear of missing out limited time offer designed to be scarce to entice buying your way etc and manipulate you into thinking you *need this right now * there needs to be some kind of a limit so he doesn't get in over his head give space to make mistakes but not enough to hang from there are adults that can't handle the spending addiction from video games and use their bill and necessity money on a virtual cosmetic dlc pack or gamble loot box i view this as a thing that needs outside moderation for children so it doesn't spiral and leech into adulthood with that said i think if it's a month that's not the end of the world just has to be monitored

it’s a dopamine response it’s like pulling the lever at a casino or checking the coin return in a machine she literally has to fight her brain about doing it now that she’s been exposed to it it’s your job as a parent to lock that stuff down you cannot operate on “good faith” alone with a kid this age you’re saying ipad and not just tablet so do the following if children in your family sharing group have their own devices use [ask to buy] to screen and approve their purchase requests [require a password] for every purchase not something guessable a random combination of symbols letters and numbers do not save it on the device you can also turn off in app purchases entirely using screen time on your own device or a child's device to use screen time settings > screen time then tap turn on screen time tap continue then choose this is my [device] or this is my child's [device] to prevent another family member from changing your settings as the parent on your device tap use screen time passcode to create a passcode then re enter the passcode to confirm in ios and later after you confirm your passcode you'll be asked to enter your apple id and password this can be used to reset your screen time passcode if you forget it use new and different codes and passwords on your child's device follow the prompts until you get to parent passcode and enter a passcode re enter the passcode to confirm in ios and later after you confirm your passcode you'll be asked to enter your apple id and password tap content & privacy restrictions if asked enter your passcode then turn on content & privacy tap itunes & app store purchases tap in app purchases and select “don’t allow” finally you can also go to settings > screen time > content & privacy restrictions and tap allowed apps then deselect itunes store and books deselect amazon and any other apps or websites that are problematic you should also [set the parental controls for amazon ] again new and different passwords you should also disable one click payments go to manage default address & one click settings > click here to change default address > click edit next to the payment method you might also consider opening a chime account and making it the default payment method this way if she slips through it gets declined do all of this

honesty she is young and she might not grasp the concept of bills and budgets not seeing money or a credit card or check might not make it click in her head that it’s money because it’s not a tangible thing for the well being of your child’s mental health and development i would stray away from punishing her with food as some have stated i would also not throw your financial status in her face explaining frugality is one thing saying now we can’t pay bills because of you is another being mindful of your lessons and how they could be interpreted by a young undeveloped mind will help some good framework for lesson learning can be “think of good deeds you can do to earn privileges” this can be behaving well using polite manners with everyone quietly doing an activity helping with housework helping put away groceries etc explaining why she cannot have the ipad until a time you deem appropriate age appropriate homework for summer enrichment maybe money or math oriented to allow for stimulation for understanding work on figuring out how it was able to happen and stop it from happening kid mode does not protect your passwords or saved payment methods so maybe that’s why is leading to it many apps allow apple pay amazon pay paypal etc you could absolutely sell the ipad for funds if necessary because clearly providing for your family is important also you could make it a password requirement for any game download and if it says in app purchases act accordingly i can see how frustrating and scary it is for you to have hundreds of dollars hanging in the balance remember it was likely not out of malice if you’re unsure of the logistics it’s likely your daughter doesn’t understand either good on you for looking for help and answers good luck

i sometimes feel like maybe i am too careful or even paranoid when it comes to in app purchases i have never entered any card info in my kids tablets or smartphones ever to get robux my kid either has to buy a physical gift card with cash or i buy a gift card for her on my phone or laptop thank you for sharing your story i feel less silly and paranoid now ask someone that would know more than you about how it all works for help remove any card info etc from the ipad before giving it back to your kid but first ask kid to show you exactly how she did manage to buy stuff online tell her you want to learn and for both your safety you will remove that option if she refuses to show you you can tell her that in that case a factory reset will be the easiest way out but she will probably lose content that way you can talk about how much money you make per hour and how many hours of your work she tried to buy virtual stuff for another thing to talk about is how gaming can be addictive and how buying extra stuff in a game feels good at first but then there is always that next thing to buy to make it _even better_ i told my y old that i have a policy for myself when it comes to games i never want to by anything in a game i grew up with computer games that you bought on a disc you purchased your game and then it was yours i dislike even the thought of being mid game and having to choose in that moment and feeling if something is worth paying for so i have chosen to never buy anything in games i told her that i understand that roblox is different from the kind of games i used to play and some i play now so i am open to her buying robux with her own money or giving her robux giftcards as presents but i also told her i _need her to understand_ that there has to be a limit how much is a virtual t shirt or some extra game really worth to her what is reasonable per year month we can always revisit those sums and what is important for her in her life might change but she needs to figure out how important it is to her now so she doesn't want to spend silly amounts o her own money and get mad at me for being boring and saying no she thought about it and decided € giftcards were reasonable as one time purchases maybe once a month but the thought of putting more than € on roblox a year felt crazy to her

i feel like you've gotten a ton of advice on how to handle this situation but wanted to offer a little bit on how to start getting your daughter to see the value of money here's what we started with my kids and it's really helped them to understand that things cost money and that we can't just buy everything each kid gets an allowance every week that is equal to their age so my year old gets per week he has to split it between three jars literally just old peanut butter jars that i cleaned out and labeled spend weekly spending money that he can spend on anything he wants no questions asked this can be purchases in games snacks at the store goodies at school whatever save money he is saving toward some goal recently his goal with to buy super smash brothers for the switch it was and he had to save for a lot of weeks to get it giving money for any kind of charitable giving usually this goes to penny wars at school or buying school supplies for a supply drive or something but they get to decide if he gets extra money for any reason like a birthday or he does extra chores and earns some extra dollars he can decide what jar to put it in most of his birthday money went into the save jar to get his switch game for the spend money they now have to use that to buy things that i don't feel like i have to provide this might be in app purchases for games extra treats at the store pokemon cards etc i also keep a box of things for them to buy at home that i have picked up when i find them each item is marked with a price and they can ask to open the store any time they want to spend the money this has greatly reduced the amount of asking for things because they know that i'll tell them they have to buy it themselves with their money for online purchases they pay me then i buy it with my card it also teaches them how long it can take to save up for something they really want which then helps them take care of it because i won't replace it if it gets lost or broken they i don’t know what roblox is but based on the comments my understanding is that it is one of those games apps where you need to pay a small fee to keep advancing in the game app apps and games like that are designed to be addictive and make you spend money i used those before and honestly they are quite addictive whenever i played and was told i had to pay for a fee to advance… i saw it as “oh it’s only i’ll pay it now and stop next time… oh wait… i’m getting to the good part i’ll pay another for now” and by the next day i’ll find out i spent on the stupid app game… and this is me as an adult with a pretty good grasp on money and using my own money so while i completely understand why you’re upset… i think you’re a bit unreasonable of your expectations of your daughter you gave her an addictive game and unlimited access to your credit card at an age where she doesn’t fully understand the importance of money and lack self discipline but you still expected her to make better decisions choices than most adults you put her in a position to fail so if you want her to learn and do better then don’t put her the position to fail delete your card information and roblox teach her about money and consequences of using it if she spent x dollars on roblox then tell her she owes you x regardless if you get a refund or not so either she picks up more chores assuming you do allowance or sell items if she’s getting allowances then maybe put it on her own debit card prepaid card and show her how to look at the transactions that way she can learn to be mindful of spending

hey i work customer service for amazon and get calls like this all the time that i then have to transfer to a special department for them to see if it can refunded every day and a lot of times the customer is baffled as to how it keeps happening i don't know enough about the parental locks on devices that carry amazon log info to point in a direction that would make sure you aren't charged with the ability to give the ipad back with full confidence that if she was intentionally doing it she wouldn't be able to with that being said if it's in the hundreds a second time i would surely hope that amazon would do the right thing and refund you i learned just how poor i was growing up at the age of after my mother died i was in a taco bell with my father and sister and had decided what i wanted to eat i told my dad i wanted two things off of their value menu at the time and he was blunt with me that i couldn't get both due to not having the money i was taken aback that the lowest of cost items were unobtainable my dad worked three jobs at that time to make ends meet because he had to quit his job on the coast to come back home and raise us full time from that point on i made it my mission to make sure that i never had to make my father tell me that i couldn't have something i wanted or needed food drove it home for me in our time of low funds i'd suggest trying to drive a point home through food even if amazon refunds you i would take that amount and divide it by and explain to her that the money that she wants to spend on her extremely momentary pleasure would cost her in other areas that she finds happiness in take each twelfth and let her know that the money is going to come out of her normal food consumption for the month if it's around ish each month that's snacks and unnecessary foods that she cannot have for that month she still gets her square meals and food that she needs but no luxuries a whole year at her age she should be able to comprehend how long that must be without your favorites snacks and such if she does this again this money will come out of other areas that she finds pleasure in toiletries that are nicer clothes that she would want outings etc money to do the extra things or field trips for school the pure embarrassment of not going on a field trip and being left at school for the day should teach any child but i digress if the situation is that there is no room to even cut these to drive a point home i'd have the conversation with her and flat let her know that this behavior in an adult is a crime that she is lucky it was your card in the account and not someone else's that she would have to contest this with i advise anyone who has had their children use their amazon account in any way such as this to never save your card to your account just add it through checkout when you place an order and let that be that yeah it's annoying to remember to renew prime that way but it's a great security step i have a nine year old niece obsessed with roblox i get it's appeal but it's like crack to children and it's crazy watching a kid play it mindlessly for hours

and this is why i bought my kid a pc instead of a tablet pc means it's connected to a microsoft account you set up the the microsoft account and you can transfer money to your kid's account and they can do what they want but seriously require a password for purchases or delete your card from the account i'd much rather go through the tedium of re entering my credit card info all the time than have to deal with purchases i didn't sanction our kid used to do this all the time with actual money he'd steal change from our change jar and it never really sunk in until one day it just did he wasn't a bad kid he just wanted stuff and it never really occurred to him that mom and dad have to work to earn the money to buy it i think i used to lie about money too there was no good reason for any of it; as gifted as i was as a child there was an element of wanting to fit in and wanting to have stuff that everyone else did and that overrides the wrongness so don't worry your kid is still a good kid but after her punishment is over you need to give her a chance to prove it one of the things i started doing was assigning my kid household chores; if he completed them he would get a small sum of money at the end of the day but rather than give it to him outright i would keep a running tab on how much i owed him this way when he wanted something he could see how much he has in theory have a moment to reflect upon why he wanted it and only then will i give him the money to buy the thing

first i am so sorry to hear about your wife my advice would be to lock your card when you do not need it set a spending cap so anything over a certain amount declines unless you authorize it i get an email for these when i have a cap set or log out of amazon and make sure the password is not saved on any devices she uses also you could enable text notifications or email notifications on purchases pretty sure you can set it for a minimal amount to inform you too i do this with my cards i get a text shortly after a charge is made telling me how much and where it was spent you can then more immediately dispute any unauthorized charges last scenario would be to unlink amazon from your payment info a pain but she wouldn't be able to do it anymore as for punishment if she stole money from anyone else she would likely have had a cop talking to her you need to tell her this is something that could get her in big big trouble i would definitely make her work around the house more than her normal chores to pay you back age appropriate chores of course i'd also really consider selling the tablet since she is proving to you that she is not mature enough for one if you have any unnecessary items unused items you could try selling them but honestly that's hot or miss you should also sit her down and discuss what a budget is and how electronic payments and physical cash works you can list out what you make per month and your bills and how much and have it show what is left over then you can explain that x is how much you should have had for the budget but because she took without asking for permission that you only have z until next payday talking finances with kids can be beneficial since it helps teach money management if your handy with excel it makes it easy to show debt to income

i think you're right to remove roblox from her access until she can control her impulses i think she needs to be taught the finality of resources my suggestion focuses on resource use give her a concrete example of how far money goes show her the grocery shopping; take her with you and let her experience what that amount of money would buy then explain that there are a lot of bills she doesn't see or understand because it is your job to manage the money show her the bills explain that the money she is taking has to go toward things like housing food light and water first after explaining that you spend your money on have to's first and the extra can go to want to's then you can talk about your role as money manager it is not her job to worry but it is not her role to spend the money because it is a finite resource she may ask for money or earn it through chores or helping neighbors perhaps but she does not have the right to simply take it lesson on stealing perhaps if she wants money show her how to earn it; that's the best lesson she can learn from this

>she was told there would again be no friends no tv or anything fun tomorrow especially just working with me outside or doing cleaning around the house i think it might be time to take the opposite tactic she may be so hooked on roblox that she's spendng on the game like an addict with the added issue of being ignorant willfully or otherwise of the consequences of her actions while a bit of cold turkey not having access to the game can help in the short term the moment she gets access back there's nothing here that's going to change her behavior you're going to need a comprehensive plan that attacks the issue from multiple angles first you need to disable her ability to make purchases putting the tablet in kids mode isn't cutting it either kids mode isn't restricting the purchases or more likely she knows how to get out of kids mode put a new pin on kids mode and don't let her know what it is don't write it down either also set up a purchase pin for any purchases through the app store as with kids mode don't tell her what it is don't write it down she's clever and probably knows where to look for these things second walk her through the charges that you needed to have reversed add them up together explain to her *exactly* how much money that is and what the impact is on your livelihoods if there are things she's wanted to buy or trips she's wanted to go on explain in those terms you spent so much money that it could have bought fifteen of the dresses you were looking at last week kind of reasoning work out with her how long it would take for her to make that much money with an allowance or a newspaper route or chores around the house or the like she's she should be able to add divide and multiply a little bit and certainly have a sense for numbers that are big give her the big numbers and make sure she understands them third outline exactly what's going to happen if she does anything like this again the mommy repayment plan can be a thing maybe she can do some housework or landscaping for family or neighbors to work off the debt and make sure she understands that it's not a joke

definitely this op this is not your year old's fault it's yours she's a child who is at an age where she doesn't fully grasp technology and in fact many kids her age don't get to use a tablet connected to the internet and especially not one that has credit card access you however are an adult and if you're going to let a child her age use that kind of tech then it's your responsibility to put a system in place that makes it so she can't make purchases not a system that requires \*her\* to exercise restraint but one that takes the possibility away entirely you might not be tech savvy but it's still your responsibility this isn't a teenager who should know better this is an year old whose brain may not quite get boundaries and rules and moral behavior like we'd like her to she'll grow into it i know it's frustrating as a parent especially considering your financial circumstances but you have to be careful not to confuse worry over the money with anger for your daughter children will remember your anger and tone of voice for the rest of their life and when you overreact they don't hear the lesson because all their tiny brains can focus on is the anger in your voice and the fear or shame they feel because of how you're reacting to them going forward take deep breaths go easy on her don't make a huge deal out of small mistakes especially ones that happen because she's little and doesn't really understand remember that her brain is developed enough for her to say the things you might want to hear like i understand or i'm sorry i won't do it again but at her age the emotional maturity the moral behavior the actual comprehension those things come down the road with lots of experience and hopefully gentle guidance from you

as someone who has studied cognitive psychology and has spent years doing user experience design for a living my professional assessment is that most free to play games are highly manipulative at best and straight up unethical at worst waiting until she has better self control will likely be a permanent ban even most adults don't have the training to recognize all the different ways that they're being manipulated let alone have practiced strategies for overcoming social conditioning needed to resist robert cialdini has written a lot in cognitive psychology about what he's deemed principles of persuasion which are general techniques that are used to influence people's behavior here's a brief summary of the principles [ his book influence is a good read if you want to dig in a little deeper [ applying some of them to a common pattern you'll see in these types of games * if you login every day you get a free reward * sets the stage for exploiting **reciprocity** \ because they did something nice for you your instinct is going to be to do something for them by complying with what they're asking * the reward gets better each consecutive day you play * exploits **consistency** \ if you've convinced someone to do something once they're far more likely to keep doing it * the rewards reset if you miss a day * exploits **scarcity** \ when something is taken away even if it's free people instinctively perceive the cost of the loss as greater than what the item would have cost to acquire * after you get the bonus you'll presented with a limited offer to purchase something only available to the first x players y players have already redeemed * exploits **scarcity** \ seeing that it's limited makes it appear more valuable and drives instinct to acquire something before it runs out * exploits **social proof** \ seeing that a large number of others have taken the offer makes you more likely to consider it a good idea to do as well * exploits **reciprocity** \ you're far more likely to take an offer because they've given you rewards

okay well i'm glad you're getting it figured out please try to keep learning don't rely on customer service reps to teach you that's not really their job especially an amazon employee trying to explain how an apple product works try to avoid using terms like kid mode and learn the actual terms for specific protections and what they mean by googling or asking questions two step verification wouldn't stop someone from making a purchase; two step verification refers to a protection that would stop someone from logging in to your account even if they learned your password your daughter didn't need to do that because you were already logged in i still think you need to consider the possibility that your daughter is the victim of a gift card scammer chatting with her and telling her to buy gift cards if that happened it's possible your daughter never even got any of the robux she tried to buy or didn't even realize she was using your account she may have thought she was just doing a favor for her friend in the game it's not super likely but there are some red flags that mean you shouldn't rule it out the fact that this happened suddenly it was a fairly elaborate scheme and it was hundreds of dollars instantly with no testing the waters makes it super suspicious you also didn't mention your daughter ever asking you to buy her robux before it would be one thing if your daughter kept asking you for robux and finally worked up the nerves to get it herself and if that's what happened then you're probably fine but if not you might be shooting yourself in the foot by punishing her for being the victim of a scammer you probably shouldn't have let her have unmonitored access to an app that lets her chat with strangers in the first place but she will interact with more people who want to take advantage of her in the future if she was being manipulated the whole thing is probably very confusing to her especially if you don't realize she was the victim of a scammer either

preteen privacy invading privacy vs proactive parenting… quick backstory my preteen stepdaughter has been caught several times engaging in very inappropriate conversations with other people online and in written letters with school mates because of this she’s obviously not trusted with electronics and social media which yes she shouldn’t be on anyway but not my house where this is happening… she does not have access to a phone or computer at mine and her father’s house and her amazon tablet is in kid mode with no access to the web and the only online “socializing” is on roblox i have always checked both hers and her brother’s roblox chats and recently saw where she was asking for phone numbers from other players i had my husband speak to her and her brother about internet safety and not to ask or give personal information both kids are expected to put their tablets downstairs at night end of the weekend before they leave this has always been kind of an unspoken rule but recently my stepdaughter doesn’t bring hers down she can’t use it after a certain time and game access is turned off after a certain time too so i’m not concerned about her being on it at night today i went to go find her tablet to check her chat and it was in a desk drawer and her roblox account had been logged out and the game uninstalled i told my husband and he said he would get her to log in and check it himself i don’t know anything about roblox so i don’t know if there are other places in the game that you can chat privately with other players a couple of weeks ago i walked in to her room while she was playing roblox and she moved as far away from me as fast as she could and sat against the wall facing the door the rest of the time she was on it are we overreacting are we invading her privacy or do we have every right to look at her stuff because of her age and of her past at what age does it become an invasion

she's at an age where you can start to teach her about financial responsibility while forming boundaries tell her she needs to work for the things she wants dole out allowance appropriate to the level of chores she can complete and let her spend her money on whatever she wants but that's it if she can't afford the item she can't purchase it if she runs out of money and wants something else she can't get it until she has earned the money and stick to it no means no it will be rough on you while she gets used to the seriousness of the situation but it will get better over time with my kid his dad has a tough time setting boundaries because he hates seeing him upset i think of it as some growing pains now for an easy pay off later this comes around when he watches our son and then wonders why he can't get him to do the same things i can it's tough but it does work

i'd recommend sitting your kids down and going over some boundaries for gifts with me my kids know they'll get gifts on their birthday and christmas and that's about it when they ask for something i tell them to put it on their list and if they still want it by either of those events there's a strong possibility they'll get it i think chores are also a good way for kids to learn the value of a dollar i have regular unpaid chores for my kids but they can earn money by going above and beyond and doing extra there are lots of resources online for age appropriate chores that start around age three your kids might not like this at first but they're young and it's easier to tackle this now

it’s a great thing for kids to start managing their own money my parents did this we were not given an allowance for doing regular chores because they wanted us to understand that chipping in with the housework was a part of life but if we wanted to earn money they would always find something “extra” that we could do to earn it they would also find ways to give us money instead of other things for example…an easter egg hunt where the eggs have dimes and quarters in them instead of candy…also a good way to reduce candy consumption when going to the store our parents would give us money usually but that was a long time ago to get whatever we want if we complained that it wasn’t enough for what we wanted it was taken away and we didn’t get anything we learned very quickly to be happy with what we got and not complain

letting kids pay for half of weekend trip i have two kids ages and this summer they have had a ridiculously successful lemonade stand they’ve averaged each day they’ve done it which has been about twice a week this summer they also get paid much less to do chores around the house so far they’ve spent their chore money each week on their own roblox or the ice cream truck but have a combined over saved from their lemonade stand our money was a little tight this summer because we’re getting ready to move we’re not struggling but vacation wise we haven’t done more than a few day trips and one weekend camping trip in years past we’ve also done a weekend trip to an amusement park about hours away with lodging that includes an indoor water park my kids have recently asked if we would be doing that again this year and i told them it’s not in the budget this year but maybe in the spring a few days ago they came to me and asked if they could pay for this years trip i’m really on the fence about it on one hand my husband and i could pay for half the trip to basically cover ourselves paying for half the trip would eat about half of their savings and we could offer to pay them back with an extra trip in the spring or just straight up cash they also don’t need the money for anything they already have savings accounts and i would rather them spend the money on a trip than candy or more toys that they don’t need on the other hand i feel like i’m exploiting my children would you let your kids contribute towards a vacation
i would let them do this but then when money is less tight put equal or greater amounts into each of their s
i think it's a good idea it teaches them the value of money and how to earn it and save it up for something they want great job on raising successful entrepreneurs from a lemonade stand is amazing

this may be unpopular to say but i think you should hear an honest take you may want to avoid buying fake brand name anything ever under any circumstance for many reasons white label or store brands can be fine but deliberate knockoffs are almost always a poor decision they tend to be foreign knockoffs with no quality control or environmental regulation employ child labor use cheaper sometimes unsafe materials and other very problematic aspects you don’t seem to be considering if you don’t want to spend the money on a certain brand of item then simply look to a brand item that fits in your budget without “pretending” to be something that it isn’t there’s no shame in wearing a basic reebok shoe or last seasons basic nike shoe on clearance if that’s where your budget is there are good quality shoes at every price point that aren’t cheap knockoffs just expand to less popular brand names and be open to less stylish or outdated models your son won’t be mocked for wearing a clean pair of adidas or nike shoes that you bought on a off sale or off a clearance rack at a shoe store or from an outlet store wearing a “fake” nike shoe or a fake anything else is grounds for being poked at kids don’t have filters they tend to *say* what adults would keep as gossip behind the curtain wearing knockoff apparel sends the message that you aren’t living within your means don’t value quality or craftsmanship don’t have self confidence or are seeking external validation it’s not a good look in any scenario save up for the real thing like your edit suggests is a much better path to take or change to something more affordable and within your means even if it isn’t the one you really want or the one that’s in style shameless knockoffs are always going to be a bad look a waste and will get you your kids judged by others

first you’re doing a lot learning a lot handling a lot and experiencing a lot all at once take a second to breathe now understand your niece is going through a lot too we don’t know the circumstances from which she was removed from her home and in your care but this behavior is not typical and she is in need of some serious therapy and quick i would call the pediatrician and the insurance and start calling the pediatrician can help get things moving with a referral and sometimes get a child into a therapist office fast when needed second no phone or internet privileges this is to keep her safe i understand you need to get a hold of her and you have options there are parental safety phones and apps and flip phones if she has an iphone there’s a parental option that she needs permission to download anything i would seriously consider a phone with no internet access as far as her school computer there should be precautions in place to prevent kids from accessing social media—i would tell the school of this incident third she’s and she does not need social media including pinterest look up what social media does and decide for yourself the correlation between mental illnesses in teens and social media is real there are law suits right now about this but do your own research and come to a conclusion fourth clearly she doesn’t understand internet danger i’d contact your case worker and see if they have advice on moving forward and also to document this this also sounds like it warrants a police report these strangers are in possession of her explicit photos minor and have been communicating explicitly with a minor lastly get yourself some help with going through this this is going to a long road of helping your niece take care and good luck one day at a time

there's a lot of good comments here that highlight the importance of boundaries and educating your daughter a yr old is old enough to start learning financial responsibility i personally would recommend a prepaid debt card that she can use for these subscriptions using her own money that she's been able to save up or that she works for these can be reloaded when they run out which also gives you the ability to limit her on how much she can spend if there's no money on the card her subscriptions will automatically cancel and you xan take the opportunity to teach her how to cancel the subscription she pays for if a prepaid card feels like too much you can also manage subscriptions with gift cards that can only be used on specific apps she needs to be able to see how her money is being spent teaching her how to use a budget can also help her but this will only work if you follow through with establishing boundaries with grandma i'd also give her an electronics time out she abused phone privileges so she looses the phone for a set amount of time when you give it back make sure she understands why she lost the phone and what the consequence was and that it will be taken away for longer if it happens again if she values having a phone she will respect the boundaries i might recommend that if a phone is important for communication then if the problem persists after taking it away more than once then you xan downgrade her to a flip phone that only has minutes these were things my parents did in similar situations when i was her age and it made a huge difference you got this mama

imo the minor obsession is typical for her age especially with games like roblox and minecraft as long as it is not interfering with daily life it shouldn't be a problem if she starts to choose the game over real life or as an avoidance tactic you may have concerns especially considering the social anxiety history in your family as far as interacting with others this is always going to be a risk with online games and apps this might be a good time for a brief conversation about internet safety and when she should bring something to you roblox does offer parental controls so you can choose certain restrictions including chat and content related controls for those under go into the game settings and you should be able to choose these options among others online features are now a part of nearly all games and it will likely only intensify as she gets older i highly recommend that she show you any game or app she starts using so you get familiar with the content you can use great resources like commonsensemedia org but user created content has the highest likelihood for slipping inappropriate content into games intended for younger users nothing beats watching her play or better yet playing it yourself

let me start off by saying roblox is full of kids but not only you need to talk to your daughter about a few things first off never give anyone too much information and **never** let anyone else know your password make sure you write passwords down accounts can have a lot of in game ”items” that your daughter probably worked hard for also warn her about scamming a lot of people trick others online to steal their items items can have value in real life don’t know if that’s the case in roblox i had an item stolen from me that i had worked hard for but in another game make sure to not take words personal and serious this happened to me but on social media i was about and someone called me a dickhead i cried and told my mom i learned from there that it’s normal and this tip is for you i am into gaming and got into it young here are a few tips take breaks this is very important and is very good to create a habit out of tell your daughter to get up while she’s playing and do some physical movements could be stretching or anything really while taking the breaks make sure to drink water staying hydrated as you know is very important and can be forgotten as time can be lost track of when playing don’t let your daughter have social medias maybe when she becomes old enough to actually have an account on most social medias i wouldn’t recommend getting social medias at all as they just affect you in negative ways and are addicting i can’t think of more right now my phone is almost dead i will go to sleep and respond to any of your questions tomorrow i might just be but i would call myself mature enough and experienced enough to know what i am talking about

i went through a similar situation with my year old boy and was absolutely floored by his behavior towards another kid in a group online bullying situation while he had other consequences apologizing had him read a kid friendly article on what bullying does to others… it’s tough to take away their phone completely one because we need to be able to get ahold of him because we’re both working parents and he’s active in sports and academics and two of how his school uses qr codes to provide access to almost everything each classes syllabus links to parent forms registration for clubs sports registration etc which is a whole other issue in itself anyway i blocked or deleted everything on his phone for two months like internet access can’t download any apps airdrop the whole nine yards basically i turned his phone into a “dumb phone” because he only had access to his camera for qr codes texting and calling i limited his contacts during certain hours through screen time on his apple phone and he couldn’t add contacts unless i approved them anyway looking back i’m glad i took it so seriously because then he had to take it his behavior seriously as well if that makes sense hope this helps

i need help with how to approach my daughter f i f let my daughter f play roblox because i thought it was safe don’t come at me i literally saw it and thought “kids game” well i installed bark on her phone which is essentially a parental app to keep tabs on your kids to make sure she’s being safe today i saw some things on the app that seemed a little weird so i checked the laptop and she was still signed in so i took a peek she has been pretending to be a boy talking to another boy about having sex with him she doesn’t know i know but i really want to have a talk about it with her and don’t know how to approach it so here i am…asking reddit does anyone have any advice on how to go about talking with her about this and the dangers of chatting online and also lying to people about who she is i’m just lost and do not know how to approach the conversation without the classic pre teen shutting down because of awkward conversation how do i tell her i found the conversation how do i keep her safe 😞

there are a couple different really important issues here number one is the chatting with strangers your daughter now knows exactly how easy it is to pretend to be someone she’s not but i doubt she has considered how easily she could be fooled by someone pretending to be a child as well in fact that could be what’s happening right now so out of a ton of concern i would approach this situation very carefully but firmly as soon as possible i have personally let my kids know this is the biggest concern and they are never to give out their names town school name etc and that if anyone is ever threatening them even with real information they weren’t supposed to give out that they can come to us no matter what we’ve explicitly explained the types of threats predators and scammers might use so that hopefully they can recognize that and still come to us i’ve described in detail how they can threaten to hurt your family how they can offer to take you away for awhile of your parents are hounding you etc all the things in my opinion knowledge is power here and i often do it in the car where they have to listen and can’t go away does she know about bark and we’re there any rules put in place where she knew you could look at her devices at any time i would be honest and concerned but try to avoid showing anger i think i would avoid any punishments at this time although moving screen time to a common room might be a suggestion

you can tell her you learned the game has a chat feature which isn’t safe for kids explain why without ever letting her know you saw her chats i think reading her chat makes sense—you needed to see if she had sent anything that could put her in danger however she will see it as a violation of privacy just let her know you saw online that it has features that aren’t safe for her if there’s a way to disable that feature and let her still play great you could use gender inclusive language in the future to help her feel safe opening up to you example “is there anyone you want to go to the dance with ” instead of “are there any boys you want to go to the dance with ”

i have been in this same situation before and the stance i took on it was that yes many of us did very similar things when we were younger but the internet is a much different and much more dangerous place now that it ever was back then my thoughts and i explained this to my child are that if they are grown enough to be talking and acting this way they are definitely grown enough to talk to me about it and learn the very real life risks and dangers of what they are doing we then had a conversation about how amazing the internet has potential to be but it’s my job to keep them safe from an ever growing atrocities that can come from being online and explained they are not old enough or have the mental or emotional capacity or be informed enough at their age to choose the safest things for themselves yet i did go into detail about the things that can happen and have real life examples because as i said if they think they are grown enough to be doing these things they’re grown enough to hear what has happened in the past i know it sounds very harsh but it is the only thing that has truly worked

not a parent but i was a kid who grew up with mostly unrestricted internet access i also use discord pretty much daily this is a tough one because the more you push the better she will get at hiding it from you i would know i got really good at hiding that kind of stuff from my mom however you should know that it's against discord's terms of service to be below the age of on their platform so she likely had to lie about her age to even make an account i think you first and foremost should find out exactly who she's talking to especially those that you don't recognize does she know them from school or online does she know how old they are are they sending her inappropriate messages that aren't just jokes or memes also does she have a cellphone if discord's on her laptop it's likely on her phone too as far as punishment trying to scare her out of doing it likely won't work there should be consequences for lying but also i understand the appeal of having a discord server for a group of friends with a shared interest that in itself should be fine as long as it's kept appropriate and from your description it looks like it hasn't been again not a parent but honestly if she's just engaging in the one server and you are worried about the content of it i'd ask to join the server so you can see the conversations and content being posted in real time if it's not kept appropriate or she makes another server to avoid you being in it then i'd go ahead and take it away completely is not old enough for unsupervised internet usage take it from someone who was that age and talking to the wrong crowd online and has many regrets regarding that edit also if you have any questions about discord i'd be happy to answer

computer can should only be used in a public place before beginning with programming you should teach the yo about computers and digital citizenship i’m currently using [typingclub] for digital citizenship and typing lessons then computer lessons on miacademy google also has a free digital citizenship game but i think typing club has much more to offer and is also free so digital citizenship is important because it teaches kids the importance of internet safety our children need to understand *why* we aren’t allowing to access the internet without being monitored they also need to understand why we need to be safe online and not share any personal information and how to be safe online but as child gets older we can remove some of the restrictions when it’s age appropriate my child has their own firefox browser that they use on the ipad as well on the ipad i can block specific urls like google youtube bing i can also change the settings so only websites that i added to an approved list can be visited so if it’s not on the approved list then it be blocked on both computer and ipad i can set the default search engine to a kid safe search engine which we’re currently using [kiddle] it redirects any searches to searching on the kiddle search engine and provides very limited results that are safe for kids kiddle also has their own encyclopedia wiki page with additional information and facts and images as well on the computer i added extensions to block sites but it’s a shared computer in our living room so everyone can use it and my husband and i have our own browser profile and the kids have a profile for them kids aren’t allowed to use the computer without our supervision mostly because they don’t know how yet and it’s being used mostly only to teach use [qustodio] free for one device upgrade to subscription for premium features more devices has time limits per app settings exclude include certain web categories exclude specific url’s monitor it all this is best because even if she connects to another wifi network the device is still locked down vs just router parental controls i wouldn’t give her access to things like google images social media etc also make sure obviously to make her the standard user not admin because then it’s possible to remove qustodio get around it as per the device itself i can speak from my own experience got my own computer when i was to learn programming it helped me quite a bit to learn the basics and get pretty comfortable would recommend [scratch] for someone her age just starting out it’s very gamified block level programming once she’s mastered that i would recommend [khanacademy programming] goes from basic to pretty advanced from there if you have a library card and your library supports it you can get free access to [linkedin learning] which has tons of courses that are super well made from beginner to advanced on basically any programming technology topic

since my spouse is a software engineer and we're both enthusiastic pc gamers we decided to bring our small human in to the tech echo system with his own pc before his own tablet phone we have our pcs all in our family office guest room so we're more able to monitor his usage plus it's less isolating than him sitting alone with a tiny screen inches from his face off in his own room we can see what he's doing we play games together or alone together sometimes etc think family lan party plus since he sees us working with computers and first helped us build ours and then actually built his with us he's developing an understanding for the 'behind the scenes' aspects of tech and media consumption we have parental controls on each element he has his own google account which is under ours and set as a minor we set it up and have the passwords his pc is password and pin locked with restrictions on when he can use it and for how long same with gaming services we've got his own accounts for things when allowable that we are the password account owners for and we curate them he has limited child accounts on our streaming services and we keep apprised of what he's engaging with obviously nothing is perfect for a while we were playing cat and mouse with him because he started getting up early and turning on the playstation to watch netflix and then to play so we had to add passwords so he started using the xbox so we had to add more passwords and then he started sneaking the switch and and and i expect we'll go through growth adjustment course corrections as he gets older he doesn't have access to youtube or social media at all yet and we won't be introducing it for years we both have sm but we don't share his photos and only sparingly post about him so he can decide the level his online presence when he's older we also make a point to engage each other and him over media we're using talking about it sharing etc so he is seeing us have a hopefully healthy relationship with it

okay so it looks like minecraft and roblox are two entirely different yet somewhat similar things * **minecraft** is a multiplayer game for pc android devices and consoles where players harvest resources and use them to create items and structures of varying complexity focus is on playful exploration and creativity with some mild social elements * **roblox** is an online game creation suite slash multiplayer environment best described as if unreal engine and second life had a child with a moderate to severe learning disability [see here] both seem harmless that said all online interactions your kids have need to be strictly supervised much like burning man is an awesome place where there's tons of cool shit to see and experience but you still wouldn't just let your kid run around completely unsupervised kids also should never go online without an adult paying close attention to what they're doing

my dad only got my brother & phone it’s one of the older ones that you slid up & press the lettered keys when we were less than double digits for safety & communication it stayed that way even till now & im as we got older he me an iphone & brother a samsung because it’s what we liked phones were a privilege if we messed up it was earned back chores were done before using our phones for entertainment on school nights we put our phones up around pm depending on age my personal feelings towards children younger than teens having + phones social media screen time is actually insane no matter age technology has negative impact on society as a whole i think kids should be kids as long as they can they need to know how to have a day framed around anything but a piece of metal battery & screen phones are distracting & addicting i think phones are necessary now but she’s only & her ipad is plenty it’s literally a bigger iphone without data i think it’s important to know how a phone works my dad knew how to put controls on it how to check history passcodes block apps etc let her brain not have the distraction & take the time now to read up on screen time the effect excessive tech screen time & social media has in children treat it like a privledge & keep boundaries up i’ve seen what a phone has done to me when i was a minor & my friends i’ve had many experiences that i shouldn’t have at the age due to some of the lack of awareness controls & other things by my parents sometimes you can’t prevent every bad thing but you can mostly edit wanted to add that i can let you know things about social media apps snap instagram tik tok etc that many parents don’t know but i personally wish more knew

what are the cool but safe online games for < year old my yo son is very interested in roblox minecraft clash of clans etc but after trying these things there’s two things i’m concerned about * predatory micro transactions the slot machine nature of some these games is difficult to manage as a kid it’s hard to understand why we shouldn’t just buy of gems * chat the ability to connect with strangers and freeform chat is a concern family members have spoken about some very purile talk all the way to very suspicious predatory behaviour with their kids i’m at a bit of a loss to find something cool that is popular that allows him to start experience online fun any suggestions

my year old plays roblox we have precautions in place but he also likes this site called abcya com you can't talk to other people on there or play with them so the social aspect isn't there if that's what he's looking for in roblox we have set up his account so no one can message him every time he wants to play a new title we check it over first most games have pretty strict rules about acceptable behavior and in my experience mods are pretty good about getting rid of those who can't follow the rules there is a running chat during most games that shows up in the corner of the screen but you can hide it bad or even suspect words are blocked with hashtags only once while watching the chat did i see someone say something racist and i was happy to see the other players jump all over that person and they were reported and removed from the game we haven't had any problems with roblox but we also keep up on what he's playing and don't allow him to privately message people or anything we check his account every few days you can spend money on roblox but without your credit card he can't and there's plenty to play and do without paying for it i don't know as much about minecraft but our local library has their own server kids can play while there or can access from home and it's tightly controlled behavior wise you might see if your library has something similar

you have to start talking to your kid about microtransactions **now** i'm not kidding you need to warn them that there are tricks built into the game to make them spend real money and would have very real consequences advise them that if they are ever caught intentionally doing microtransactions they are forbidden from playing video games until they're old enough to understand why tell them that there have been children who racked up hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt in accidents from some of these games additionally as far as chat is concerned it can be turned off of most games most games that allow children under the age of don't have verbal chat or have a very restricted type chat have a conversation with your child about how people online talk to each other let them know not only that there are people who can be rude but there are also people trying to trick him online too best to go ahead and work in any conversations about bullying or long distance communication that you need to at this point these are all conversations you need to have before your child goes online if you listen to this advice though they'll be fine if you try to only find games to work around this problem instead of just having the conversation with them enforcing it you're going to regret it source i did this with my kid when he was he's now and he's fine and has never accidentally bought a game or a microtransaction be aware of what your kids are doing be familiar with the games they are playing be ready to answer questions as they come up and you will never have the problems you were worried about

my kids are we play a lot of minecraft online and not and we also play roblox they get the ideas of what video games to try out based on what they hear from schoolmates and what they see on popular youtube channels of other gamers we have some boundaries first off their screens can be seen from my desk i don't make a deal out of looking at what is happening on their screens but if i see something that border on inappropriate i make a subtle suggestion hey that looks like something an adult might watch and they know to change channels or do something else i know i cannot stop them looking at inappropriate stuff i can only guide them; if they want to be naughty or sneaky it can happen anywhere at school a friends house the library computers my approach is to guide but be open to questions and support at all times the do get friend requests but we've already had the talk about how only people they have met in real life can be accepted as virtual friends i also point out that virtual micro transactions are worthless and the stuff you buy can be played for they do get steam vouchers occasionally and i tell them to spend wisely or lose out i usually select their games or guide their choices and they have a good idea already of what is 'adult content' versus what is 'kid appropriate' something else you might run into soon email confirmations for games and distributions eventually you will get tired of having your youtube channel filled up with roblox promo content and you will have a hard time registering your username and your kid's usernames on the same email address for some titles or services yep they have to have an email address of their own at some point i made a domain for my family and i manage the email i have it mirrored to my inbox and i can see what is coming and going before they do to reduce the spam overhead i chose a domain name that is uncommon and i do the registering of products to be sure the check boxes for 'send more stuff' are not set in the future minecraft will have it's own currency system i understand this move it to compensate plug in and map developers better you can check out the r minecraft sub for updates and a better explanation i go there often for build ideas or resource pack announcements there is a sub r mcservers in which you can search for family oriented minecraft servers or you can just make your own it's not too difficult
my daughter started roblox at she started to chat i deleted it right away too many creeps even in dedicated rooms sad but true

if you want something different you could download world of warcraft you can play up to level for free you can't send in game mail make a party or private chat on the free version there is a general chat that's moderated but you can just shut it off my year old loves making new toons exploring doing the low level quests and trying to help other players it's fun to watch her try and communicate with other players using only emotes roblox has been great for her i was against it for awhile but the game has good parental controls we have the private messaging shut off but left the general chat turned on she has to play it out in the living room so we can monitor her behaviour and the other players behaviour it's been great she gets to practice her spelling and learn to interact with people online in a pretty darn safe environment someone did call her a newb it made her sad even though she didn't know the meaning of the word we explained what it means how it can be said in a mean way or in a joking way she learned about how you can't express sarcasm online very well she took a break from the game for a bit and then started playing again i know you want to keep your kid safe online the best way to teach them is to let them have online experiences now in places that are easy for you to control and monitor

i would give him opportunities to earn the extra he gets for being a part of the family and doing his normal chores and then put value on things that aren't done and allow him to take initiative and do them even better help him start his own business if you're in a neighborhood show him how to advertise his services for mowing lawns pet sitting dog walking car washing etc if he's crafty show him how to sell his merchandise on etsy he's at the age where he can start creating real value for others he could potentially earn a lot more than an extra per month and it will mean something to him show him what accountability means in a work setting and set him up for success in the future

i give my year old allowance weekly he has chores during the summer time he rides on the mower and will do some gardening with me and my outdoor chores and he will help maintain the living regular common areas grades are a given along with keeping a clean room and doesn’t get rewarded for that he cannot dip below a b i do believe if he’s working for his money and he decides how to spend it he recently saved up and bought a switch lite he has also blown a lot of his cash on fortnite and minecraft and has been disappointed especially when weve went to the target or something and he’s wanted something and i refused to buy it it’s been a lesson for him on how to properly save his money and not buy something because it initially looks good i also did this same thing with my now year old who has a part time job it’s worked for us

how to handle my childs f youtube success hi everyone i'm wanted to ask advice on the following my daughter likes video editing and has been running a youtube channel focused on roblox minecraft etc fanfiction content recently her channel has grown to the point where she has over subscribers and some of her videos have over million views this means that if i were to monetize her channel she could potentially earn a significant amount of money i'm proud of my daughter for her effort and dedication to her channel but i'm also unsure about how to handle the financial aspect of this my current plan is to open a bank account in her name which she will gain access to when she turns however i want to make sure this is the best approach or if there are other considerations that i should be thinking about with her best interest in mind i'm thinking about a wide range of topics from her wellbeing to the practical side like * not monetizing at all because i dont want just the money to be a driving factor i want her to do things she love and not only think about money * but then again she loves making editing these videos so it would be quite the accomplishment for her to get paid for it * collegemoney * just let it sit in an account * investing the money i try to teach my daughter to be independent and to let her make as much of her own decisions as possible so i would like to include her in the process of deciding on how to handle it as of now she knows that she has a lot of subscribers and lots of views but since she never uses money because well she's and doesn't need money she got no clue that a this can make her serious money or b what serious money even is so my question is what advice do you have for me as a parent in this situation how should i handle this situation how would you handle this any suggestions or feedback would be greatly appreciated

parents can potentially provide their pov here but also ask this question on a financial subreddit they might provide an alternative that you are not thinking of personally i would monetize the channel this is the most practical step you can take it as an opportunity to teach your kid financial matters

i feel like an account for the money to go in and her have access once she is is a splendid idea maybe leave a little out here and there for her to spoil herself to like robux or new games but definitely explain how saving it is very important for most of the money it’s awesome she has done so good to the point of getting so many views

i would ask this over at investing or a personal finance sub if you do this find a high yield savings account then an investment advisor not something like a basic bank savings account keep her involved but keep the focus on saving look into your state's plan or another college savings instrument edit do that last bit regardless of what you decide

i don’t know much about this but you absolutely should monetize the channel but obviously provide super tight supervision for example disabling comments this could set her up with her first car a college fund house down payment etc but these things can be fleeting so if you hem & haw over it you may miss your moment there’s no reason not to monetize it and save the money to benefit her later i wouldn’t even tell her it was

if she doesn’t know it can make her serious money and you want to consider her well being and have her continue to do something she likes without thinking about money is there a way you can monetize the channel and take the money and put it away for her into some sort of investment account or a high interest savings account that she can access later i think if she’s really good at it and is getting a lot of views followers it would be worth monetizing and saving that money for her since life is expensive and only getting more expensive honestly not sure how you’d go about it in the future if she knew she was making a ton of money and wanted to start using it so that’s something to consider either way that’s awesome and congrats to her she deserves to be paid and her talents could really get her somewhere

also ask in personalfinance personally i’d suggest monetizing it but be very careful is she anonymous if so take steps to improve anonymity never mention name location school city etc ensure her account is not easily traceable etc if not anonymous it’s not a deal breaker but be careful even more important is mentally this is probably something that is short term will stop making money in months or a year it is extremely important for you to embrace that and not push her to continue it or blame her once the viewers and money falls off let her keep being a child financially set up a account at fidelity or similar the account is in your name with her as beneficiary she can spend it on college tuition room and board computers also trade school private school it can also be used to fund her roth ira up to k invest in a target date fund for the year she turns inside the roth ira if she earns more than some amount for example years of expenses at a state university allowing for growth above that invest in a different account

monetize it quietly if you can make an account for her don't have her think about ups and downs with the money don't make it a thing if she gets treat her to something amazing disney day or something if she's raking in thousands put that money aside let her know later hey when you were a kid you made a bunch of money and give it to her to give her a leg up at a stage in life why say no to money

just my perspective monetize it but don't let your child know that you are doing so at this time she doesn't need to know at years old that way it will still be fun i'd keep her name off of everything possible online to provide as much anonymity as possible as for the finances personally i'd put them in long term investments tied into a trust if this has the potential to be as successful as you think it might it would be worth setting it in trust with options for withdrawl for specific items like education and other necessities related to advanced education ie technology a vehicle travel etc naming you as trustee with full distribution at that way she won't squander it on fun stuff before it is used for the things that will actually give her a brighter future i've seen too many people blow windfalls quickly i remember a teen in college who spent most of an inheritance on buying friendships drinks all around concert tickets etc and i've seen adults spend a million inheritance in a few short years living off of it instead of investing it and allowing it to continue growing in that situation they were almost broke by retirement and struggling to make mortgage payments the best thing you can do for her is tying it up and teaching her about personal finance so when she does take it over she has the skills to continue to grow the money

you could put the money into an account like an utma an account that she can only access when she hits a certain age i'm interested to see other replies i have no clue how to handle this newfangled technology for my kids

i would absolutely monetize the channel and get an accountant to answer any tax questions i would have all the money earned would be saved towards my child’s retirement imagine years of compound growth just for doing something that brings you absolute childhood joy schooling and otherwise invested for their future at she may not care about money but it’s a perfectly fine age to start learning about it she can also get a say in how she invests it like buying roblox stock though she should also learn that buying individual stocks is a highly risky endeavor that should constitute only a small percentage of a portfolio that is heavily invested in broad market index funds and get a real head start in terms of her financial literacy and well being so proud of your kid for you op make some and if your daughter finds that she doesn’t like it then she should have control over when to end the monetization

if you monetize it and it sells i would suggest you set up a trust fund realize you could be talking about a few hundred dollars or tens of thousands of dollars technically she wouldn't be earning money you will according to google's rules i wouldn't be afraid to use that money for her upbringing and expenses as well a trust fund is a good idea because it can be managed imagine giving an year old child on their birthday how many good financial decisions are they going to make and how soon before the money is simply gone people that age are just starting to truly learn about money and expenses side note i've seen couples in their 's receive a windfall and its gone in two months in summary upbringing college savings investments trust fund

i would be looking at this from a different angle i grew up in the dawning era of the internet when open chat was entirely the norm most of the games i was playing when i was your daughter's age had completely open chat your daughter will likely continue to play these games whether you want her to or not the only thing that will change if you forbid ones with open chat is that she will get better at hiding those ones from you video games are a socialization tool for modern kids especially now in the age of covid this is where her friends are which may or may not be the same ones she has at school and this is how they hang out the absolute best thing you can do with her is to teach her proper netiquette help her learn how to spot threats and predators explain to her what information is ok to share what music she likes what her hobbies are etc and what information is not ok to share her age where she lives what school she goes to her e mail address or social media etc make sure she knows how to use the block and report functions of any game she is playing make sure she knows not to send or accept any files that someone sends her and and this is the important step that i think far too many parents skip because of how uncomfortable it can be to talk about explain why explain how there are scammers out there who want to mine her for information so they can potentially get access to her or your accounts and financial information or get a virus onto her machine explain how there are predators out there who want to hurt her or coax her into sending them pictures of her naked give her the grim details because it will help contextualize why the rules that you're setting exist kids generally understand rules if you explain out the reasons behind them and will react better to those than blanket bans
